Sir:-

I beg to advise you that the plumbing in the toilets and bathrooms at the Sandy Bay Residential School is in very poor repair and is in places dripping through to the floor below. A number of toilets are not in use due to lime deposits in the bowls as hard as cement. The work done by Mr. Babb of Portage la Prairie is still in good shape.

In view of the state of the plumbing, I asked Messrs Cadham Hardware Company of Portage la Prairie, to give me a price on the repairs needed, and beg to attach herewith their price, together with the detail of work required, which is very complete. I beg to suggest that the toilets in the dormitories be moved to the other side of the building; this matter was discussed with the Reverend Principal, and he agreed with the idea. The septic tank is on the East side of the building, and all the toilets are on the West side of the dormitories, which means that all the pipes run across the building to the main. By moving the toilets, a more direct run to the septic tank would be made, and lime deposits from the water would not so readily clog the pipes. I could not obtain a price on this work as the plumbers had left. The ceiling in the girls dormitory is in need of repair; patches 6 to 7 feet across have recently fallen down. The boys playroom also requires patching and is badly in need of painting. The outside steps to the rear entrance also require new treads etc. I have not received a report on the test of the water at the school, although Doctor Cadham informs me that there is considerable magnesia and sodium chloride present.

The Act. Deputy Secretary,

Ottawa, December 18, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, relative to the repairs and alterations required to the plumbing in the toilets and bathrooms at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, and enclosing a quotation which you received from the Cadham Hardware Company for the performance of the work.

In reply I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are entirely assigned. Only the really necessary improvements can be considered at the present time, and you may have the repairs absolutely necessary carried out in order to place the toilets in a condition satisfactory for use until next summer. You may also have the ceiling in the girls' dormitory repaired. Any expenditure incurred should be kept as low as possible. We are noting for our Estimates for the next fiscal year an item for the repairs to the plumbing, moving of toilets, etc., at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

Sir,

I enclose herewith voucher No. A.664, amounting to $43.75, in favour of Messrs Cadham Hardware Co., Portage la Prairie, Man., for stove and boiler complete for the use of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

I might say that Mr. Alfred Babb was out to see this boiler and on his return he advised me that he was unable to get a stove to fit this boiler, these being out of make a number of years, but he would make a casing for same for same but would not guarantee it to be satisfactory. DR. SCOTT

I am quoting for your information the following from a letter addressed to the Minister by Mr. W.A. Smith of Amaranth, Manitoba, who has been drilling a well at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School:

"Now a word or two about this new well I have drilled here. I have got a large flow of water here. Have pumped it with an engine for two days and have not dried it. The Indian Agent sent some away to a laboratory and it contains magnesia and sodium chlorite. Now the priest has been cooking with this water and it makes good tea and he seems very pleased with it. I got some of this water in the other well but not so strong as this, we thought it was A.I. water, and if I were you I would quit at this flow, the rock below this vein of water is full of mineral, look at the country all around is amaritite gypsum and soda, and there is not a good water well between here and Kintons, this flow is down 125 ft. There are three other wells on this place and it is only fit for cattle, you cannot cook anything with it and the nearest good water here is in shallow wells."

Your files contain a memorandum dated October 18, addressed to the Minister, from which you will observe that the department made an allowance of $160.00 to Mr. Smith for tools lost in connection with this work.

Private Secretary.

Dear Sir:

On December 29th we received a sample of water from well at Sandy Bay School. For the purpose of identification this was given our Lab. #4101.

The following is analysis of the water:

| Substance       | Results (parts per million) |
|-----------------|-----------------------------|
| Calcium         | 443                         |
| Magnesium       | 120                         |
| Sodium (calc)   | 914                         |
| Sulphates       | 1971                        |
| Carbonates      | 19                          |
| Chlorides       | 1040                        |
| Total Solids (evap) | 4790                     |
| Alkalinity      | 31                          |
| Total hardness  | 1199                        |

The analysis shows this to be an excessively hard water and it will have a serious effect on both boiler and plumbing system. We also think that the water is much too hard for domestic purposes despite the fact that Dr. Cadham's bacteriological examination has showed it to be a safe water. We
J. Waite. Dec. 31, 1930.

mean by this that the high content of sodium sulphate may give rise to intestinal disarrangement. We would, however, suggest that as the well is a new well and has been put down where the soil contains a good deal of alkali, the excessive hardness may be due to some of the alkali soil having got into the well and that by pumping out the well a number of times the water may improve in quality.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto a report by the Provincial Bacteriologist also a report from the National Testing Laboratories on the water in the new well recently drilled at the Sandy Bay Residential School.

I stopped drilling operations as soon as the sample of water was taken, the well being about 137 feet deep. According to the test the water is not good for household purposes. I have not taken up the matter of drilling deeper with the driller, but I am of the opinion that the Sulphates are contained in a vein of water at a depth of about 52 feet, this is a very heavy vein of water and I asked Mr. Smith to be especially careful and see that this vein was blocked off before drilling deeper. A considerable quantity of cement was used in trying to block off this vein, without apparent success. Will you please advise further in this matter. I might say that this water is apparently good to taste, and no ill effects have been experienced.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, February 2, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd ultimo, enclosing a report of the Provincial Bacteriologist, also a report from the National Testing Laboratories, Limited, Winnipeg, on the water in the well which was recently drilled at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say it is noted that the analysis shows this to be an excessively hard water and that it might have a serious effect on the boiler and plumbing system; also that it is too hard for domestic purposes. I have to request that you will state whether this supply of hard water is being used for domestic purposes, i.e., for drinking and cooking, and, if so, if there have been any ill effects. You might also state whether it would be feasible to obtain the soft water required for use in the boilers from rain water from the roof, run into a cistern. It is noted from the report of the National Testing Laboratories that the excessive hardness of the water may be due to some of the alkali soil having got into the well and that by pumping out the well a number of times the water may improve in quality.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.
Requirements of Sandy Bay Indian Res. School.

1. Repair of walls; interior decorations almost in every room.
   Also painting of the outside.

2. Repair of stairs.

3. Dough mixer (Capacity 2 sacks) and a motor for same.

4. Electric Plant.

Remarks:

The Sandy Bay School is in a miserable condition: No repair to the walls and no painting done for many years. The lighting system is dangerous and gives a poor light. For the last three years I have asked a dough mixer for this school. It is the only school in this part of the country having none. Kindly send one as soon as possible.

Ottawa, March 26, 1931.

Dear Dr. Scott,

Pursuant to our conversation of today, I have now to write regarding one of the most urgent improvements among the ten Indian schools in our province. I refer to the plumbing and sewage disposal at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. It is true that the Department made some improvements two and three years ago, but I regret to inform you that conditions are yet far from satisfactory and, in fact, I might describe them as deplorable.

Will the Department arrange to have a competent plumber visit this school and prepare a statement, showing what is really required during the next two or three years or as long as this building is used? Of course, he would prepare an accurate estimate as well. I would like to suggest the name of Mr. J. Yates, of Brandon, in whom our Order has every confidence.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Duncan C. Scott, Esq., F.R.S.C., Litt. D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 28th, 1931.

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Dr. Scott,

I wish to confirm our conversation regarding the need for a dough mixer at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. I have made inquiries and I am inclined to recommend Fletcher Single Arm Dough Mixer of one barrel capacity. I understand this is manufactured in Toronto. Father Chagnon informs me that he has no engine suitable for operating the dough mixer and, as he has no electric power, I have to request that a 3 H. P., Type "Z", Fairbanks-Morse Engine be supplied.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Both the
SANDY BAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

Both the classrooms were tidy and well aired. The children were clean and neatly dressed. All the boys had their hair closely clipped, consequently it needed no attention. The girls' hair was neatly trimmed and nicely combed.

The classroom work examined was good, and the children spoke out well. Their books have all been well cared for, and those in use as exercise books I found to be neat, and the work carefully set down. The handwriting, in most cases, was good.

The dormitories I found to be clean, and the beds all neatly made. Both rooms were well aired with plenty of windows admitting an abundance of light.

The sewing room is bright and well equipped. The girls receive excellent training in this department, and do good work.

The laundry is equipped with hand washing machines, which no doubt make the work much slower than the power machines, but give the girls a training more in line with what they will be obliged to use at home. The cement floor is in poor condition, and portions of it need to be renewed.

The kitchen is small, and consequently often very warm. I understand the girls are taught bread making, as well as other plain cooking, and under this department they are also instructed in the art of buttermaking.

The building was clean throughout, but dull and gloomy. No painting or decorating has been done for years, so that the place appears neglected. The plaster is bad.
SANDY BAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D)

bad, and in several places patches have fallen off. I understand this is due largely to defects in the plumbing, due to rust and corrosion. The water is very hard and eats into the pipes and taps, and I would judge that a thorough overhauling of all plumbing is the first thing needed before any plastering or decorating is done.

The front and rear steps leading to the building are in bad repair, and should be renewed. The Rev. Father Chagnon claimed that the eavetroughing leaked badly and should be renewed. The soft water is used for drinking purposes, and is none too plentiful, so that an effort should be made to save as much as possible.

The fire equipment is in good repair, and extinguishers are located at points throughout the building. I think, however, that two more extinguishers should be provided, one for the girls' dormitory, and one for the workshop, which joins the furnace room, and in which is located the forge and acetylene lighting plant. I do not think the forge should be in this building, and I doubt the safety of having the lighting plant located in such close proximity to the furnace. If this room were discontinued as a workshop, and an electric lighting plant installed, the risk of fire would be greatly reduced. I would again emphasize that I do not consider the present arrangement safe. The fire alarm consists of a triangular iron suspended from the wall. This is a poor arrangement, and cannot be heard throughout the building. A proper alarm should be installed, which will operate throughout the entire building.
I had fire drill while there, and found considerable delay, mostly due to the fact that the alarm had not been heard by all.

The meat required is raised on the farm, and each fall the winter's supply is killed and hung in the storehouse. I found 14 quarters of beef, and 18 or 20 hogs still to be used. The weather had turned mild, and the Reverend Principal expected to cure most of the hams and pickle a quantity of beef in order that none be wasted.

The milk cows are selected from the stock herd of about 60 head, and during the greater portion of the year 10 to 15 cows are milked. I understand there is rarely a shortage of milk, and the butter made is used at the school.

The children are well fed, and have plenty of vegetables and meat, as well as bread, tea, and grease.

Poultry is kept, and is well looked after, with the result that plenty of eggs are secured.

The grain produced, with the exception of a small amount of wheat, is used on the farm for the production of beef, milk, and eggs, and this produce is used in the feeding of the children and staff.

The garden last year was good, and plenty of potatoes, turnips, carrots, and onions still remained in the cellar.

No children were sick, and they all appeared contented and happy.

This fall a well was drilled, and a good flow of water secured, but unfortunately the water is so saturated with minerals that it is unfit for human consumption. Water has always been a problem at this school, and the outlook of obtaining

of obtaining a satisfactory supply is not encouraging.

The school is filled to capacity, and I learned that there are at least twenty children of school age on the reserve unable to receive schooling. It seems unfortunate that arrangements cannot be made whereby these children may receive some education.

The Rev. Father Chagnon is assisted by the Rev. Father Poulett, a farmer, a mechanic, and a staff of Sisters.

Dear Sir;— Re Sandy Bay Indian Boarding School.

I am in receipt of a report from our Inspector in charge of the Neepawa District who has made a fire inspection of the above mentioned school and recommended as follows:

(1) That the two and a half gallon soda and acid type of fire extinguisher on each floor should all be recharged and date of same recorded on tag attached to the fire extinguisher. He also recommends that two more extinguishers of this same type should be installed, one on the boy's dormitory and the other in the workshop.

(2) There are two outside fire escapes of the sliding pole type, one from a landing outside of the boy's dormitory and one from a landing outside of the girl's dormitory. There is also an outside stairway leading down from the landing of the girl's dormitory which is in a very unsafe condition, and as the sliding pole is supposed to be used for descending to the ground, he would recommend that this stairway be demolished or shut off to prevent any of the children using it in its present condition.

There is only one exit door to this landing, which opens outward, and is o.k.

In the boy's dormitory there are two doors in the doorway leading to the outside landing. The outside one, or the screen, opening outwards, and the inside one opening inwards. He reports that the inside door is kept locked with a padlock, and he recommends that all existing doorways be made to open outwards, and that this door should be kept unlocked and some arrangements should be made so that this door should not be locked.
(3) Acetylene gas is used for lighting the building, this gas being generated on the main floor. The compartment in which the gas is generated is near the furnace room; in fact, the furnace room and gas generating room are in one with no dividing partition of any kind. He recommends that owing to the fact that the building is occupied, this gas plant should be eliminated all together and an electric light plant installed. Failing this, however, the gas generator plant to be isolated entirely from the main building.

(4) In the work shop on the ground floor of the building there is a grain chopping outfit, the power for which is furnished from a gasoline engine. The engine is in the same room and is not partitioned off. The gasoline for the engine is fed from a tank just on the outside of the basement wall, the gasoline being kept in a 40 gallon drum placed in a wooden box with lid close to the wall of main building, without any protection and which is not even kept locked. It is recommended that some arrangements be made for this engine to be kept in a fire proof room with self-closing fire door. Gasoline should be stored in an isolated building, under lock and key, where there would be no interference by the children occupying this school.

(5) In the vegetable part of the cellar there is a small stove used for heating purposes. There is at least 60 feet of stove pipe from this stove to the chimney, and in several places it is too close to the woodwork, and is immediately below the gas generating plant. This piping is a very serious menace, and it is recommended that a solid brick chimney be erected to take care of this stove, thereby eliminating the serious fire danger of almost sixty feet of stove pipe.

I am forwarding this report for your information, and at the same time forwarding a copy of same to J. Grove Smith, Dominion Fire Commissioner, and I would be pleased if you would kindly give the matter serious consideration.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I received this morning from Mr. J. R. Bunn, who advises me that a copy has also been forwarded to the Department, a letter enclosing a report from the Deputy Fire Commissioner at Winnipeg in connection with conditions at the Sandy Bay school as they affect protection and the fire hazard there.

Five points are dealt with and numbered. Several of them were dealt with by Inspector A. G. Hamilton in his report of his visit to that school which was forwarded to you under cover of my letter of the 28th ultimo.

The first item deals with fire extinguishers, and I agree with the recommendation that those now in use should be recharged and two new ones installed.

The second item deals with the outside fire escapes and recommends the use exclusively of the sliding to the exclusion of the outside stairway, which it is pointed out is in an unsafe condition and ought not to be used. It might either be demolished or egress to it shut off altogether. Under this head reference is made to two doorways in the exit to the outside landing in the boy's dormitory. The practice of locking these exit doors is common in many of our residential schools, and, that all principals may be reached, I think a circular should be addressed to them pointing out that the main reason for supplying fire escapes is defeated if the exit to them is barred. I am aware of the reasons advanced by principals for keeping these doors locked, but some other method must be devised of preventing their use by the pupils to clandestinely leave the building. In this instance I am writing to the Principal on the subject.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Number three draws attention to the use of acetylene gas and the close proximity of the compartment in which it is generated to the furnace room. A recommendation is made that the gas plant should be eliminated and an electric lighting plant installed, but failing this that the gas generating plant should be entirely isolated from the main building. These recommendations are reasonable, but as the Department is aware this is a very old building and I am very doubtful of the advisability of expending money in its repair or in effecting any radical changes which would absorb a large outlay. However we must take note of the Fire Commissioner's recommendations.

Number 4 deals with the inadequate protection given to the gasoline tank which contains the supply for the engine used in the workshop on the ground floor of the building. Clearly a change ought to be made here and the gasoline stored in a proper tank situated away from the building where danger of fire and explosion would be reduced to a minimum.

The final item, number five, draws attention to the use of a stove for heating purposes in the vegetable cellar, the outlet from which to the chimney is covered by sixty feet of stove pipe. Such an arrangement is clumsy and dangerous, but the danger is enhanced by the fact that this part of the cellar is immediately below the gas generating plant, a combination which immediately suggests it as being dangerous.

As I observed in my covering letter enclosing Inspector Hamilton's report, the condition of this building does not in my opinion warrant the expenditure of a great deal of money. On the other hand, the observations and recommendations of the Fire Commissioner must be met, at least in part and where they can be without great cost. The safe storage of gasoline, of course, ought to be insisted upon and probably the erection of a brick chimney from the vegetable cellar would reduce the risk that now exists owing to the use of sixty feet of stove pipe. Extinguishers can be provided and instructions given as to their disposition, and it ought also to be made clear to the Principal that from time to time all of them should be emptied and recharged. There will then be the assurance that they will work effectively in case of an emergency. I doubt if it will be necessary to demolish the outside stairway, but in any event its use should be prohibited. It would probably not cost a great deal to re-arrange the doors in the boys' dormitory so as to allow of their opening outwards

- and when -
and when the change is effected it should be insisted that they be not looked. The cost of installing an electric plant instead of using the present acetylene gas lighting arrangement will entail an expenditure which may not be warranted in this building, but a re-arrangement of the present plant might be provided for if the outlay would not be too costly.

As I am anticipating that the Department would write me on this subject, I thought it well to express my views.

Your obedient servant,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Cautions

1. WATER ANALYSIS
OPERATION and CAPACITIES of Duro Softeners are WARRANTED ONLY when chemical analysis of water to be softened has been made by us or where reliable analysis has already been made and report sent to us for recommendation.

Duro Water Analyses are made free of charge. Analysis cannot be made unless at least one quart of water is sent in thoroughly clean glass containers. Address, Engineering Dept., The Duro Company, Dayton, Ohio.

2. SOFTENERS ARE NOT FILTERS
If water contains sediment when first drawn, filter must be installed ahead of softener. Organic growth and mineral salts deposit from some waters on standing or during shipment which does not allow us to state definitely as to the necessity of a filter on these waters.

Softeners are made to SOFTEN WATER and not to FILTER WATER. Any water that requires CLARIFYING, due to IRON, MUD or any other FOREIGN MATTER, must be passed through a FILTER before being passed through SOFTENER or the softening mineral will be clogged by foreign matter, and its capacity will then be affected.

3. IRON IN WATER
Iron is always present in water but usually in small amounts. It may be dissolved (invisible) in the water, or it may be in the form of rust (discoloration). Iron dissolved in the water will settle (precipitate) in the form of rust when coming in contact with air (oxidation).

When present in quantities above .12 grains per gallon it causes iron stains in laundering, on the fixtures, etc.

Water having iron in it in the form of rust will contaminate the mineral and affect its capacity. The water should then be filtered before it enters the softener.

When the iron is dissolved in the water, it will oxidize immediately on being exposed to the air, or air in sufficient quantities may come in contact with it in the pipe and form rust.

Write the Duro Company for information on how to remove dissolved iron from the water.

4. SALT IN WATER
Considerable SALT is PRESENT in some water on account of salt deposits in the earth. Salt in the water REDUCES the softening capacity of the mineral. How much, can only be determined by a chemical analysis which we make free of charge (see Water Analysis).

5. SALT USED FOR REGENERATION
Hard fine-grained salt takes up less space than the soft flaky salt. Therefore we recommend the uses of a fine granulated salt both for hand and automatic softeners. Rock salt, however, can be used as it takes up about the same space as does the hard fine-grained granulated salt.

It is necessary that the salt used be of a very high grade both as to sodium content and freedom from dirt. It should contain at the very minimum 99% sodium chloride. It should be free from any material that does not dissolve in the water such as fine quicksand, which it is practically impossible to see in the salt.

The ordinary ice cream rock salt usually contains considerable ordinary dirt and should not be used.

PURE SALT gives BETTER REGENERATION and CLEAN SALT prevents the pipe lines from clogging up. (Send 1-lb. sample for approval.)

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier

OTTAWA  
Ontario

Dear sir,

I have just returned from a visit to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

The repairs to the plumbing system authorized by the Department are completed and I understand that the work is satisfactory. There is still a very offensive smell emanating from the soil pipe that goes through the classroom occupied by the girls. Father Chagnon intends to call the agent's attention to this matter on the occasion of his next visit to the school.

Father Chagnon tells me that the wheel and gears of the windmill must be replaced without any further delay. This windmill supplies the water for the sewerage system of the school and if anything happened to it, especially in the winter time, conditions in the school would be very bad. This windmill was supplied by the Ontario Wind Engine and Pump Co., who have a western office in Regina. The present installation has lasted for the last 15 years. The total cost according to Father Chagnon would be from $75.00 to $100. I would suggest that you authorize Father Chagnon to purchase the necessary repairs or to advise the Ontario Wind Engine and Pump Co., to supply them. I beg to call your attention to the urgency of this matter as great damage would result to the water supply system if a break-up would occur in the winter. Father Chagnon tells me that if the windmill were out of action during the severe weather for more than one day, that the pipe leading into the well would freeze up.

I was informed that the dough mixer and gasoline engine which your Department promised to supply to Father Chagnon have not yet been received. As this machine is urgently needed, I hope that you will order same without any further delay.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6276, file 584-5, part 4)
Your Department has in the past furnished three small washing machines and ringers about every three years for the Sandy Bay School. The present machines are worn out and should be replaced immediately. As the Sandy Bay School has possibly the worse equipped laundry of any school, I hope that you will take Father Chagnon's request favorably.

The refectory tables are in very bad condition. They were originally made with flooring, laid cross wise. Through natural wear and shrinkage of the wood, there is an opening between each board which is filled with dirt and cannot be cleaned. There being a carpenter on the premises, I believe that an outlay of not more than $50.00 would be sufficient to either make new tables or put new tops on the present ones. I would appreciate it very much if you would give instructions to that effect.

I noticed that there are not enough pews in the Chapel for all the pupils. This shortage has existed for several years but as the pupilage has been increased by 5, it is now more acute. I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would supply 5 small pews about 5 feet long similar to those now in use. The present pews are about the simplest article that can be made. They have no back and no kneeler. The carpenter who is now doing the repair work could easily make these pews.

I was told that there is no provision in the estimate for the carpenter work that is now being done for painting. It would be unwise, it seems to me, to leave the outside stairs without a coat of paint. A small additional sum to the one you are now spending would take care of this item.

As Father Chagnon has been most reasonable in all his demands respecting his school, I hope that you will be good enough to give the various items mentioned in this letter your favorable consideration.

Yours truly,

THE REVEREND GREAT FATHERS

Dear Sir;

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant enclosing an account from Mr. George Ball covering an estimate on work at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. Sir,

Before writing to Mr. Murphy, I got
Mr. Smith to write you stating my claim,
and you want me to give you a detailed
statement. Now do you think I went up
to Sandy Bay for my health. You asked me
to go and you should be man enough
to pay me. The Indian dept or Mr. Murphy did
not ask me. You are no man & I wrote
to you to pay me. Had you offered to give
me any thing in reason I should have
been quite satisfied and saved all this trouble.
I did not want to bring it before Mr. Murphy,
as he will have enough to answer in the
House about the way that job was handled
and other appointments. I have been
asked to make a statement before 6 members
one a good Liberal & you will be
surprised to have the photograph of that
man slap in the private room where I fell.
and I carry the marks yet. I could have claimed $500 damages from the Dept. Several lawyers wanted me to let them go ahead it. You must know that there are a lot of very disappointed men over Mr. Murphy getting that appointment & are all trying to get some thing against him. Now I turned them all down - I felt that when you got thru with the work that you would figure in what you would give me for my time and you never even thanked me. Now there is nothing left for me to do but to give Mr. Murphy a chance to see that I get my money or I shall sue for it & let the Judge assess my claim. After the New Year I will get Mr. Smith to get in touch with Mr. Murphy.

Yours Truly,

George A. Ball

January 18, 1932.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Pursuant to phone conversation, I have to send you a letter with enclosures from Mr. Indian Agent Waite, with reference to the claim of Mr. George Ball, of Gladstone, Man., for a fee and expenses in connection with last year's repairs at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

You will remember that your memorandum of April 29th authorized the engagement of Mr. E. J. Cresswell, of Gladstone. He was asked for an estimate. Your memo of June 5th directed that Mr. Cresswell be removed from the list and that Mr. George Ball and others be substituted. The Indian Agent was so informed, and, on his own initiative, he, on June 24th, wrote Mr. Ball asking him for a price. A copy of Mr. Waite's letter to Mr. Ball is one of the enclosures.

I sent you a memorandum concerning this work on July 21st and on August 3rd you authorized the engagement of Mr. Cresswell.

With reference to Mr. Ball's claim, I may say it is not usual to pay a tenderer a fee and expenses, but the terms of Mr. Waite's initial letter to him were somewhat unfortunate. Mr. Ball might easily understand that he was to be given the work.

With the return of the correspondence, will you please let me know the Minister's wishes.

Encl.

Duncan C. Scott

Dear sir,

I have just returned from Sandy Bay where I went with Rev. Father Magnan, Provincial. We undertook the journey in response to a call from Rev. Father Chagnon.

The water supply of the school is worse, if possible, than it used to be. As you know, the attempts made at drilling have been a failure. The water that was found is unfit for consumption and is so hard that it clogs up in a short time all the water service pipes.

Father Chagnon is of the opinion that a fairly satisfactory permanent water supply could be had by damming the creek which runs West & East on the school property. This creek is about 300 feet distant from the school building. Father Chagnon informs me that there is running water in that creek every Spring and that occasionally, there is also running water after a heavy storm. There is a fall from the school towards the lowest point in the creek of about 9 feet. If the bed of the creek as well as its slopes were dug three or four feet for a distance of about 200 feet x 100 feet wide, a storage sufficiently large would be had, which in Father Chagnon's opinion, as well as in Father Magnan's and myself, would give the school a sufficient quantity of water. A
home-made filter could be installed at the east end of this reservoir and the water that would thus be had would be in our estimation, far superior to anything they now have, even lake water. Lake water in itself would be preferable of course, if it could be piped to the school. As it is now, Father Chagnon has to haul lake water, but as he has no pumping system, the water has to be taken at a short distance of the shore at a depth not exceeding 18 inches. This water, especially after a storm, is so full of foreign matters, that it is not fit to drink.

Would it be possible for you to send an engineer from the Waterways Dept., in Winnipeg to inspect the possibilities of damming the creek and establishing levels.

Owing to the present depression, Father Chagnon is of the opinion that the work could be done at a very reasonable price, especially if he were given free hand in the matter. If I am not mistaken, $1000 were set aside for general repairs to the Sandy Bay School. Father Chagnon is of the opinion that this amount would be sufficient to build a water supply large enough for the general needs of the school.

Father Chagnon took occasion of my visit to remind me that he has not as yet received the dough mixer which has been promised him for the last 2 years. As the estimates have been passed, I don't see any reason why this should not be attended to immediately.

Several of the Principals which I met three weeks ago told me that they had not yet been notified of the amounts granted.
their schools in the last estimates for general repairs and improvements. Would you be good enough to write to them and inform them about it.

I would appreciate a copy of the letters that you will write them.

Yours truly,

Sir:

The problem of a suitable water supply for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, at Marius, Man., has engaged the Department's attention on several occasions. I understand your office has never been asked to make a recommendation in this connection, as there has been considerable doubt about the advisability of indefinitely continuing the school at its present site. Your officers, however, did assist with the sewage disposal system, in 1927 - your file 15844-W.

The Church authorities have now made a suggestion that the creek which runs past the school be dammed and an outdoor reservoir prepared. There is not sufficient water in this creek at all seasons of the year to consider it as an ordinary source of supply.

There is no intention on the part of the Department to expend a large sum of money at this institution. However, it is desired that a survey be made, to determine the feasibility and approximate cost of damming the little stream. There are natural banks, about 150 feet apart, which could be used.

Would you be good enough to arrange to have your Winnipeg office make a survey at the earliest possible date? I understand that an accountable cheque for expenses for one of your Winnipeg engineers has already been directed to your office.

I may say that it is hoped, in the event your officer reports favourably, to have this work undertaken by the management of the school, using Indian and other local labour. Therefore, you might instruct him to give the Rev. Principal, upon the occasion of his first visit, advice as to where to put the dam and how it could best be constructed.

INTRODUCTORY:

On August 4th the writer, accompanied by Mr. J. T. Ross, Assistant Engineer, made an inspection of the suggested reservoir site for a water supply for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. Sufficient instrument work was performed with level and compass to permit of the drawing of a contour plan of the creek valley for 1,300 feet upstream from the immediate school grounds. Sufficient borings were also taken along the most practical dam location to determine the nature of the foundation conditions. The inspection enabled us to study the water supply situation at the school, to ascertain the purpose of the proposed reservoir and also to determine what would be involved in the creation of the same.

TOPOGRAPHICAL FEATURES:

A small creek valley passes between the school building and the barns and it is along this creek that it is suggested that a reservoir be created. The accompanying contour plan shows the creek valley as it extends some 1,300 feet above the school grounds; sta. 90+00 being in line with the school garage. At Sta. 5+00 on the right bank and within the creek valley is situated the hog-pen, and from Sta. 0+00 to Sta. 6+00 is utilized as a hog run with a consequent rank growth of weeds, etc. Between Sta. 6+00 and 7+00, there is the remains of an old beaver dam in a clump of aspen trees. Above Sta. 8+00 and extending to Sta. 14+00, the banks are cultivated. At Sta. 14+00 the creek emerges from a fairly heavily treed area. It is said that the creek has its origin about three miles away.
distant, but in all probability the creek valley is not well defined for more than half of that distance. The creek valley, as shown on the plan, is shallow and the rise very gradual, being only 3.6 feet in 1400 feet.

RUN-OFF CONDITIONS:

Information relating to the flow in the creek was obtained from the Principal of the school. Flow usually occurs for a period of two weeks to one month at the time of the spring freshets and during some years after heavy summer rains. In the years 1922 and 1923 flow continued during the summer months but such heavy conditions are unusual. It is difficult to estimate the maximum flow as no measurements were taken, but it is probable that a flow of 20 C.F.S. might be experienced and have to be provided for in the dam construction.

The spring of 1932 was quite dry and the Principal stated the creek flowed for two to three weeks. A flow of even 2 C.F.S. over such a period would be ample to fill any reservoir that it is suggested might be created at the school. While there remains some uncertainty in the mind of the writer as to the dependability of flow in this creek, yet such information as has been obtainable, is to the effect that flow occurs yearly at the time of the spring freshets and in amount sufficient for the purpose of filling the required reservoir.

WATER SUPPLY REQUIREMENTS:

The school authorities estimate the water requirements to be 3,000 gallons daily or 1,100,000 gallons yearly. In comparison with other schools, such a rate of consumption appears conservative, and it is quite probable that were an adequate water supply available the daily consumption would be nearer 5,000.

It will show immediately the basis of our calculations. Water is required for watering the crops and domestic uses and that the area below stock, sanitary purposes and for cooking and washing.

RESERVOIR POSSIBILITIES:

The school authorities have suggested placing a dam across the creek valley from Sta. 0476 to Sta. 7400 and up to contour 826.0 on account of the to impound 2,000,000 gallons of water, of which it was estimated they would utilize 1,100,000 yearly. This suggestion has been considered and in connection with the same the most favourable location for the necessary immediately above the lake to provide adequate dam selected. Any reservoir created to provide adequate for the common practice estimates a loss of two feet depth on small water supply must be capable of impounding sufficient water at the time of the spring freshet to take care of losses due to ice formation during the freezing period and the reservoir must provide for water usage during the entire year. In Manitoba common practice estimates a loss of two feet depth on small reservoirs from evaporation annually during the open water period. Again common practice provides for ice formation to a depth of three feet on small reservoirs during the freezing period, making a total loss of five feet on a reservoir from these two conditions. The gain from rainfall is usually neglected. These losses in reservoir depth are of the greatest importance in the creation of a reservoir in this creek valley at the Sandy Bay Indian School.

Examination of the plan accompanying this report will show that in our opinion the most favorable site for a dam across the creek valley for impounding purposes is at Sta. 0476. The general contour of the ground will only permit of the construction of an earth dam to elevation 826.0 with a maximum reservoir elevation
of 824.0. Such elevations will necessitate dyking along either bank above the dam for some considerable distance. It will also be noted that the elevation of the creek bed exceeds 818.0 and that the area below contour 820.0 is small indeed. While it would be necessary to remove the soil to a depth of twelve inches throughout the creek valley from Sta. 0450 to Sta. 7400 and up to contour 825.0 on account of the area being used as a hog run, this additional twelve inches becomes of minor importance. It would also be necessary to excavate from within the creek valley immediately above the dam to provide suitable materials for the construction of the dam and the dykes along the bank. Approximately 1000 yards of earth would be required for these purposes, but even the removal of this material would only appreciably enlarge the reservoir area above the dam. With reservoir surface at elevation 824.0, it would be possible to store in excess of 2,000,000 gallons of water at the time of the spring freshets. It is quite obvious, however, that with no inflow and with the reservoir drawn down two feet by evaporation and an additional 1.5 feet by usage during the open water period that the water supply would become depleted early in winter through the formation of ice and further usage. It might be pointed out, however, that such a reservoir would probably furnish an adequate water supply for the period April 15th to December 31st of each year and at a fairly moderate cost. Later in this report an estimate is given of the probable cost of such a reservoir. Because of the immense losses in depth due to evaporation and ice formation, the depth of water of
reservoir becomes all important, the greater the depth in proportion to area, the less the losses. To provide a deep reservoir in this creek valley considerable excavation is required, the depth of excavation under ordinary circumstances being governed by the economics of the situation. The governing features in this particular problem are the nature of the material to be excavated and the necessity of having a reservoir of sufficient depth so that after providing for evaporation, ice formation and usage during the open water period, there remains sufficient depth of water to ensure a water supply during the winter months.

The construction of an earth dam to elevation 826.0 and the building of dykes are still required as is also the cleaning up of the reservoir area and the removal of the hog-pen. The Principal of the school stated that from their observations made during construction work, sinking wells, etc., hardpan was usually encountered about eight feet below the ground surface. At the time of the inspection we were unable to take any boring in the creek bottom at elevation 818.0 on the dam line because of the hardness of the material. It appeared to be hardpan and doubtless hardpan would be encountered at elevation 818.0 throughout the area to be excavated.

To obtain the minimum requirements of water supply the reservoir must have a depth of nine feet below elevation 824.0 and have a bottom area of 36,000 square feet. It is proposed that the reservoir be rectangular in shape, 240' x 150' with side slopes of two horizontal to one vertical. Such a reservoir located between Sta. 1400 and Sta. 4400 will necessitate some 9,900 yards of excavation, probably 5,000 yards of
which would be in hardpan or material equally difficult.

With the construction of the dam and dykes to elevation 826.0 and the excavation of the reservoir just outlined in excess of 5,000,000 gallons of water could be impounded in the spring. However, at the beginning of winter the water level in the reservoir would be drawn down to 820.5 by evaporation and usage. Allowing ice formation to a depth of three feet would leave 2.5 feet or 562,500 gallons of water available for winter use.

The estimated cost of creating this reservoir is given below.

ESTIMATES OF COST:

The cost of the dam, dykes, clearing of reservoir area, replacement of hog-pen and fencing of the reservoir, are the same for both schemes outlined above. It is assumed that the Department would be called upon to replace the present hog pen with a new structure. No estimates of cost of piping or for pumping are given. The estimated costs for excavation are considered conservative when compared with cost figures furnished by the Water Supply Officials of the Railways, and taking into consideration the conditions under which the work would have to be carried out, it is considered essential that the reservoir area be cleaned out to a depth of twelve inches up to Sta. 7400 and that the hog-pen be removed. Some 2,400 yards of earth would be required moved in this process.

### REMARKS:

The writer is definitely of the opinion that such a source of water supply is unsuited for drinking and cooking purposes and should not be utilized for such purposes. The water supply would be subject to contamination, vegetation growth will develop in the stagnant pool, giving the water a disagreeable taste and offensive odor. In all probability the Department would be called upon later to provide facilities for sedimentation, filtration, chlorination, softening and possibly cooling in order to provide a satisfactory water supply for drinking and cooking purposes. This is an important point in connection with any decision as to utilizing either of the two schemes outlined.

Undoubtedly the water supply situation at this school is very unsatisfactory. The cost of the outlined scheme for providing a twelve months water supply is prohibitive. It would be more economical.
and satisfactory to render useful the present salty water from the wells now in use. The scheme outlined for use during the open water period will furnish water for stock and sanitary purposes only, leaving unsolved the problem of a satisfactory water supply for drinking and cooking purposes. It is possible to improve present conditions at the school by providing additional cistern capacity and providing facilities for a measure of filtration through powdered charcoal of the water supply between the roof of the building and the cisterns. However, this phase of the situation has not been thoroughly inquired into by the writer.

Dear Sir:

We received advice from Mr. A. F. MacKenzie, Secretary of
the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, that the 2 H.P., gasoline engine
which was supplied by the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company apparently is not
strong enough to drive the dough mixer, which we supplied you, sometime ago.

We consider that for ordinary doughs, 1 H.P., delivered at the
mixing arm is enough power. With a belt driven machine, however, the amount
of power delivered at the mixer, depends a great deal on the efficiency of
the belts, as considerable power may be lost through belt slippage and so forth.
There is also the possibility, that your present gasoline engine is not properly
adjusted and if there are any gasoline engine mechanics available at Amaranth,
we would suggest that the engine be inspected, as the timing may be out or some
small adjustment may be necessary.

We would also be pleased, if you could advise us the diameter
of the pulley on the engine, the diameter of the pulley that the engine drives
and the diameter of the pulley that drives the mixer.

With this information, we would then be in a position to
advise, if the mixer is travelling at the correct speed.

Sir:

Dear Sir:

About a year ago the water situation for the Sandy Bay Indian school was taken into consideration by the Department and engineers were sent out to calculate the possibilities of improving the water conditions.

Nothing has been accomplished as yet and I would be much obliged to know whether some little improvement could not be done. For your information permit me to outline our difficulties in obtaining drinking water.

We have two wells which would furnish a sufficient quantity of water, but it cannot be used, being that it is alkaline. To use the lake water is practically out of the question because the hauling distance as well as the quantity required is too great; hardly we have the rain water to depend on, but unhappily these woods are not always clean. As this last source is about the least, would it not be possible to have some kind of a filter installed so as to greatly improve and render this water suitable for drinking purposes.

Trusting that you will favorably consider this suggestion, I wish to remain,

Dear Sir:

Regarding the drinking water situation for the Sandy Bay residential school, I wish to say that to date it is becoming more and more urgent that something be done. As you are aware, the question was brought up two years ago, but the plans then proposed proved to be undesirable. Last fall we were advised to await the visit of Mr. J. D. Sutherland and to discuss the matter with him. Unhappily he was forced to cancel his visit and with winter setting in and with sleigh roads to haul water from the lake, we dropped the subject.

This spring we are still more embarrassed than ever as we haven't even our usual quantity of rain water. We have had so far only one barrel-full of water from our roof, which I may say was far from being fit to drink.

Hauling from the lake is no small task either especially during our ordinary spring work, and considering the distance and difficulty to reach water, only about three tanks can be hauled in one day, which is very little.

I have a plan which I wish to propose to you, and I believe it would bring better results: Could the Department supply us with: A motor truck; a tank and pump and about 100 ft. of 2in. pipes.

With this equipment we could, at least in my estimation, supply ourselves with water more suitable for drinking purposes, as it would facilitate hauling and therefore we would not be obliged to fill our cistern and then let the water stand till all is consumed.

I trust that once more you will be kind enough to consider the matter.

I remain Dear Sir,

Yours very sincerely,

REPORT ON
WATER SUPPLY SITUATION
AT
SANDY BAY INDIAN SCHOOL.

On Tuesday, June 26th the writer visited
Sandy Bay Indian School near Amaranth, Manitoba,
accompanied by Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector, Department
of Indian Affairs, Winnipeg. Mr. Wade, Indian Agent at
Portage la Prairie and in whose district the school is
located was also at the school in connection with treaty
payment. The water supply situation was fully discussed
with the Principal of the School, also different schemes
for improving the present unsatisfactory conditions.

The existing water supply at the Institution
is briefly as follows: The school building is approximately
100' x 40' and rainfall upon the roof is collected into an
underground cistern 12 feet in diameter and 10 feet deep,
with a capacity of about 7,000 gallons. This cistern is
in close proximity to the kitchen and the water is
delivered to the kitchen by means of a hand pump located
in the kitchen. This water is used for drinking, cooking
and laundry purposes. For sanitary purposes three tanks
with a combined capacity of 2,200 gallons are located in
the attic of the building and a gravity water furnished
the school. The water supply to these tanks comes from
two sources, but the quality of the water is much the same.
A comparatively deep well, approximately 250 feet from the
school, is operated by a wind mill and a feed pipe leads
to the water tanks, the energy necessary also being supplied
by the windmill. A comparatively shallow well is located
quite close to the workshop of the school and is connected
to an underground cistern nearby; the dimensions of this
cistern being about four feet square and sixteen feet deep.
A pump driven by a small gasoline engine located in the workshop connects with this cistern and also to the storage tank in the attic and is operated during such periods as continued lack of sufficient wind to operate the windmill results in failure of water supply from the deeper well. The Principal of the School stated that this shallow well appeared to be going dry. The water from both these wells is very hard and distinctly salty. It is unfit for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes in the school, but I understand that in addition to sanitary purposes it is also used in the steam heating system, high pressure boiler and domestic water heater.

The amount of water that can be collected into the soft water cistern from the roof, even in a year of average precipitation, is far from sufficient to meet the requirements of the very limited use to which this supply is put and consequently water has to be hauled from Lake Manitoba - two and one-third miles distant. The hauling is done by team and a 400-gallon metal tank mounted on a wagon is used. It appears that only an average of one tank per week is hauled from the lake.

While exceptionally light rainfall has been experienced at the school this spring, I would not say that water supply conditions at this Institution now are worse than they have been for several years past. However, conditions have been very unsatisfactory for many years past; they never were good, and the Principal and staff of the Institution have carried on year after year under very trying conditions, resultant from the nature of the water supply. Mr. Wade informs me that the annual expenditures for maintenance of the heating and plumbing system is very large and is undoubtedly due to the nature of the water supply since the salty water is utilized.
Consideration has been given to different methods of providing a more satisfactory water supply but the fact remains that a satisfactory water supply cannot be assured except at a cost that must be considered prohibitive when consideration is given to the age and condition of the school. The cost of rendering the hard salty water fit for general use would be prohibitive and there are no facilities at the school for the operation of approved softening devices. Pumping the water to the school from Lake Manitoba would involve a large initial outlay and also a large annual operating charge for pumping etc., as the lift is considerable. The impounding of spring run-off in artificial reservoirs is not feasible at this location and the run-off conditions in the vicinity during the past two years have definitely proven this to be so.

From an economic viewpoint, therefore, it would appear necessary and advisable to carry on at this school with the present sources of water supply - unsatisfactory as they undoubtedly are. However, it is possible to alleviate somewhat the trying conditions resulting from the present sources of water supply by providing equipment whereby a more adequate supply of Lake Manitoba water can be utilized in the Institution. In comparison with other Indian Schools, it is apparent that the soft water supply at Sandy Bay School, augmented as it is by hauling from Lake Manitoba, is conserved to a point where the Institution and its inmates suffer.

I would recommend, therefore, that the Department of Indian Affairs give immediate consideration to the purchase of equipment that will render it possible for the school to haul water from Lake Manitoba to the school rapidly and in such quantity that a much more
extensive use of this water can be made in the Institution. The equipment required, with the approximate cost of the same at Winnipeg, would be as follows:

I. Truck Chassis fitted with cab and built for load of 3½ tons. Single tires on rear ---------------------------------------- $1,340.00

II. Steel Tank 42" dia. x 10' - 3/16 plate - Saddles and Fastenings --------------------- 135.00 25.00

III. Double Action Hand Pump ------------------ 25.00

IV. 100 feet of 2" hose ---------------------- 50.00 Strainers etc. ----------------------------- 18.00

$1,600.00

It may be possible to reduce this estimate by utilizing a Ford Truck Chassis; the cost of which would be approximately $1,000.00, thereby reducing the estimated cost to $1,260.00.

The writer would also suggest that if the above equipment is provided, certain changes be made in the Institution to make possible more extended use of Lake Manitoba water during certain periods of the year. Lake Manitoba water should be used in the heating system, in the high pressure boiler and domestic water heater, rather than the salty water now used. To use Lake Manitoba water when available would necessitate shutting off the connection between the shallow salty water well near the workshop and the small cistern, utilizing this cistern as a reservoir for hauled Lake Manitoba water and pumping the water from this cistern to one of the three storage tanks in the attic. It is probable that a new 1" pipe line would be required from this tank to the connections to the heating system, high pressure boiler and domestic water heater. However, savings effected in replacements would warrant the small expense involved in making these minor adjustments.

As a general rule it would be impossible to haul water by truck from the lake during the winter months although some winters it might be carried on for the greater portion
of the winter. However, in winter water usage is not so heavy and furthermore there is less for teams and labor to be kept busy at.

I understand that the Principal of the School originally suggested the supplying of a truck for water hauling. When questioned on the subject the Principal stated that if the equipment as recommended be furnished, he would be well satisfied. I am sure the equipment would be well cared for and believe that water would be used in much greater volume in the school and do much to eliminate the dissatisfaction that has been evidenced for years towards the water supply. With adequate quantities of water in use a general improvement in the welfare of the inmates of the Institution would naturally result.

Acting District Chief Engineer.

January 19, 1935.

I beg to refer to my memorandum dated November 27th, last, regarding the request of the Principal of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, Marius P.O., Man. (Federal District of Neepawa), forwarded through the office of Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man., that urgent repairs be carried out to the laundry drying room at the school.

You authorized that James Dalton, Neepawa, visit the school and report on the work required and the cost of same. Mr. Agent Waite was instructed accordingly, and he forwards a report from W. H. Dalton, Tinsmith, Plumbing and Heating, Neepawa, Man., giving, in detail, the material and labour required to the amount of $392.46. Mr. W. H. Dalton also states that, to the above amount, the sum of approximately $10 be added in case there are some extra fittings needed when the repairs are being made.

There are funds available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year to provide the expenditure required.

I would request to be advised if Mr. W. H. Dalton may be engaged to supply the material and labour in having the above repairs to the laundry at the Sandy Bay School carried out.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, January 23, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing an estimate, stating in detail the materials and labour required in carrying out the necessary repairs in the laundry at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with W. H. Dalton, Neepawa, Man., to supply the materials and labour in having the repairs carried out. It is noted that the cost, for materials, labour and transportation, will be $382.46 - to which should be added the sum of approximately $10.00, in case there are some extra fittings needed when the repairs are being made. You should request Mr. Dalton to have these repairs completed as soon as possible.

After the work has been finished to the satisfaction of the Principal and yourself, you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, setting forth in detail the materials supplied and their cost and also the number of hours of labour employed and the rate paid. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. These accounts should reach the Department before our books close at the end of the present fiscal year. The entire expenditure incurred should not exceed the above stated amount.

Your obedient servant,

THE HONOURABLE THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL:

The requisition for drugs and surgical instruments referred to in the latter part of the telegram is probably the usual requisition for drugs for the residential school. Doctor Lerner is a part-time physician, and the Department does not supply instruments to such employees.

The account for the cabinet and the requisition for drugs are in all probability on their way to Ottawa. When they arrive I shall report further.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

The Right Reverend Dr. Simott, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Winnipeg, has addressed a letter to the Minister, from which the following is extracted:

"I have just returned from a visit to the Indian missions in the northern part of my jurisdiction and I think it my duty to lay certain considerations before you. The missions I visited covered the Reserves of Shoal River, Birch River, Pine Creek, Waterhen, Crane River, Ebb and Flow and Sandy Bay. I found the Indians on these Reserves, with the possible exception of Pine Creek, in a pitiable state of destitution. The fishing and the hunting this year have been almost a failure, and as a consequence the Indians are without sufficient food or clothing. I personally receive all kinds of demands (I enclose a sample) and I try to give some help in every case, but you can realize that this should be a matter for Government support and not for private charity. May I ask that you request some one of your army of agents and inspectors to look into the situation.

May I now take the liberty of directing your attention to two other matters that concern me greatly:

1. Winnipogosis. It seems to me that there should be a hospital built at this point for the care of the Indians and Half-breeds. There are 1200 Indians and Half-breeds on the Pine Creek Reserve and in the adjacent country, there are Half-breeds settled all around the shores of Lake Winnipogosis, and across the Lake there is the other Indian Reserve of Waterhen. A Hospital at Winnipogosis would be a most humanitarian way of helping a large number of people who have extreme..."
need of hospital care and who are so far removed that they are practically without it. A Hospital at Winnipegosis would be serviceable also for the many fishermen who frequent this Lake both in winter and in summer. I commend this project to your earnest consideration.

2. Sandy Bay. The Residential School at Sandy Bay is not only inadequate to meet the needs of the Reserve, but it is in a most disgraceful, not to say disgusting, condition. This School is in your own Constituency and you must be familiar with it. Either a new School should be built in a more convenient situation, or the old School should be thoroughly repaired and considerably enlarged. This matter has been under consideration for so many years, that it were time indeed that some definite conclusion be reached."

The Minister would appreciate a memorandum covering the matters referred to, which will enable him to reply to His Grace.

[Signature]

Private Secretary.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Buskard -

I have to refer to your memorandum of the 5th March with extracts from letter from Most Reverend Dr. Sinnett, Archbishop of Winnipeg.

I am attaching memoranda from Mr. Parker with regard to the question of relief and from Mr. Sutherland in connection with the Sandy Bay school. In regard to the latter I would also refer you to page 6 of my report of September 8th. Last, following my visit to Western Canada, my reference to the Sandy Bay school is as follows:

"We paid a visit to the residential school. Father Chagnon, the principal, has a fine collection of mounted birds and a nice garden. Outside of these two features there is very little concerning this school building that is worthy of commendation. The building is very old, the fire hazard great and upon first consideration one would doubt the advisability of spending more money in attempted repairs or renovations. As you are aware, the question of a water supply is a very great difficulty at this point."

From Departmental experience in the administration of this school and from information obtained on the occasion of my visit, I am of the opinion that serious consideration should be given to the closing of this school.

With regard to the question of the erection of a hospital at Winnipegosissi, I may say that the Director of Medical Services advises me that while it is stated that there are 1200 Indians and Half-breeds in this district, only 200 of these are Indians. In the event of there being funds available for the building of a hospital for Indian patients in Manitoba, there are other localities where the necessity is greater and which would be more suitable than Winnipegosissi.

With reference to the providing of an adequate water supply system for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, the Dominion Water Power Branch was requested to have Mr. Gow, the District Engineer, visit the Sandy Bay School and submit a full report with recommendations and estimate of the cost of providing a new water supply system.

A report has been received from Mr. Gow through the Dominion Water Power Branch here. This report outlines what is required in connection with the proposed layout and gives estimate of cost. Detailed drawings have not been prepared as these would require several weeks in preparation. If it is desired to proceed with the project these drawings will be prepared. Mr. Gow's estimate of the cost of the proposed installation is $23,281.50 which is made up as follows -

(a) Intake $7,330.00
(b) Pipe Line $8,470.00
(c) Pumping System $1,050.00
(d) Distribution System $3,965.00
Hauling - Railway to job $350.00
Workmen's Compensation, Contingencies, Engineering, Inspection, etc., 10% $2,116.50

$23,281.50

I might add for your information that the existing water supply system is briefly as follows -

The school building is approximately 100' x 40' and rainfall upon the roof is collected into an underground cistern 12 feet in diameter and 10 feet deep, with a capacity of about 7,000 gallons. This cistern is in close proximity
to the kitchen and the water is delivered to the kitchen by means of a hand pump located in the kitchen. This water is used for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes. For sanitary purposes three tanks with a combined capacity of 2,200 gallons are located in the attic of the building and a gravity water furnished the school. The water supply to these tanks comes from two sources, but the quality of the water is much the same. A comparatively deep well, approximately 250 feet from the school, is operated by a windmill and a feed pipe leads to the water tanks, the energy necessary also being supplied by the windmill. A comparatively shallow well is located quite close to the workshop of the school and is connected to an underground cistern nearby; the dimensions of this cistern being about four feet square and sixteen feet deep. A pump driven by a small gasoline engine located in the workshop connects with this cistern and also to the storage tank in the attic and is operated during such periods as continued lack of sufficient wind to operate the windmill results in failure of water supply from the deeper well. The Principal of the School stated that this shallow well appeared to be going dry. The water from both these wells is very hard and distinctly salty. It is unfit for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes in the school, but I understand that in addition to sanitary purposes it is also used in the steam heating system, high pressure boiler and domestic water heater.

The amount of water that can be collected into the soft water cistern from the roof, even in a year of average precipitation, is far from sufficient to meet the requirements of the very limited use to which this supply is put and consequently water has to be hauled from Lake Manitoba - two and one-third miles distant. The hauling is done by team and a 400-gallon metal tank mounted on a wagon is used. It appears that only an average of one tank per week is hauled from the lake.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, September 18, 1935.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have your memorandum of the 20th instant, with attached correspondence from His Grace Archbishop Simott, Winnipeg, regarding the condition of the building at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, and also a communication from the Principal, Reverend Father Chagnon, O.M.I.

This school is located on the Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, No. 5, Manitowah Agency. The history of its establishment is as follows:

In 1905, the Roman Catholic Church authorities erected four Indian Residential Schools, viz.: Sandy Bay, Fort Alexander, Kenora, and Fort Frances, which they turned over to the Department, in exchange for the Residential School which was conducted at that time in St. Boniface.

Since that time, considerable expense has been incurred on all the above named schools, in providing additions, alterations and repairs, but, notwithstanding the expenditure on these buildings from year to year, they are still in an unsatisfactory condition. The Sandy Bay School is in a more unsatisfactory condition than the other three buildings. It is very poorly located; the building is now very old, the fire hazard great, and it would only be a waste of money to attempt further repairs or renovations. The building is not large enough to accommodate the number of children of school age on the reserve. There are 130 children of school age, and the total number that can be accommodated in the Sandy Bay School is 75. Even at that, it is overcrowded.

Efforts have been made, during the past few years, to obtain an adequate water supply, but no satisfactory solution

Encl.
solution has been found.

The Department obtained, from the amount provided by the Public Works Construction Act, an allotment of the funds required to erect a day school building on this reserve, to provide classroom accommodation for 40 children. A site was chosen and plans prepared, but this work has not been proceeded with. The funds are still available, and it is considered that the erection of a day school during the coming summer, in addition to the accommodation at the residential school, would provide educational facilities for all the children on the reserve. It is proposed to proceed with the work of erecting the day school next summer.

Undoubtedly, action will need to be taken in the near future to replace the present old building in use at the Sandy Bay Residential School. Officers of the Department have visited this school from time to time, and all have reported on the condition of the building and the lack of proper water supply. At present, water is being drawn, by a motor truck, from the lake, a distance of three or four miles. The Department has supplied a truck, with water tank, for this purpose.

The problem of providing educational facilities on this reserve might be solved by the erection of day schools. However, I am quite sure that the closing of the residential school would meet with strong opposition from the Catholic Church authorities.

As requested, I return herewith the correspondence which accompanied your memorandum, including three copies of the translation of the communication from Father Chagnon, the Principal.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Relative to the attached communication from His Grace Archbishop Simnett, requesting that provision be made at an early date to erect a new residential school building on the Sandy Bay Reserve, to replace the present old building, I would say that no funds are provided for this purpose in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the coming fiscal year.

The present building was erected in 1905, and, although considerable expense has been incurred since that time, in making alterations and repairs, it is in a very unsatisfactory condition for school purposes. There is a considerable fire hazard and, besides, great difficulty in obtaining a water supply.

It will be necessary, before building operations are proceeded with, that a new site be obtained on the reserve, where an adequate supply of water for domestic and fire purposes is available. The Department understands that a site with adequate water supply can be obtained on the reserve, a distance of three or four miles from the present school. It will be necessary to obtain a surrender from the Indians of the Band of the area of - land required
land required for school and farm purposes.

I am unable to state when it will be possible to provide the necessary funds to erect and furnish a new building with accommodation for 120 children. This would involve an expenditure of approximately $130,000. The Archbishop might be informed that the need of a new residential school on the Sandy Bay reserve will be kept in mind and favourable consideration given when possible to obtain the necessary funds. The staff of the present school will, no doubt, be able to carry on, even under existing handicaps, until such time as it may be possible to erect a new building.

I do not consider that it would be advisable to choose a site for the school until it is definitely decided to proceed with construction. However, the Department would have no objection to His Grace proceeding with the erection of a church, provided that a surrender from the Indians is obtained and this is forwarded to the Department, together with a surveyor's description of the proposed site of the church. Mr. Agent Waite, Portage la Prairie, is the proper officer to arrange with the Indians of the Band for a surrender of the area of land required for church purposes.

Deputy Superintendent General.

My dear Archbishop Sinnott:

Ref: Sandy Bay Residential School.

In reference to the suggestion contained in Your Grace's letter of January 13th, regarding the immediate selection of a site for the Sandy Bay Residential School, I would say that this would appear scarcely feasible on account of the severe weather conditions now prevailing in Manitoba. Without complete information on the subject I would consider that this is a matter that might be deferred until the ground is clear of snow, when a tentative site could be selected for utilization, in the event of a school being erected at a later date.

Before the matter of a site is finally decided upon, I should like to have our Departmental Architect review the situation as, in the past, the Department has been subject to unnecessary expense, through ill-advised action, in the selection of sites for residential schools.
