EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR HAMILTON DATED APRIL 16, 1936, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SANDY BAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The fire hose on the first floor was detached, because of a leaky valve. This valve should be renewed.

The plumbing needs repairing in several places. One break on the ground floor will involve considerable expense as the flooring will have to be renewed. The pipe from the well to the school is also frozen or broken and all water used is now being hauled from the lake. The new truck is used for this purpose and has given good service. I noticed many of the taps are badly corroded and, before long, a large amount of repair work will be needed.

The furnace is in need of repair, but no doubt this can wait until summer. It appears to need a crown plate and possibly grates. The brick work on one side is badly in need of repair. In one place it is open two or three inches; in fact, pieces of brick have fallen out.

The stove for heating the root cellar has about 70' of pipe which runs along the ceiling to the furnace room. I understand this was not in use during the past winter as the vegetable crop failed. In my opinion this is a most likely source for a fire and the stove should not be used again with the present arrangement of pipes.

I received no complaints of any kind in connection with the school. The Department, of course, are aware of the condition of the building and also the inadequate and unsatisfactory water supply.
Sir,

The sewerage system at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School is badly blocked. The staff at the school have done everything possible to clean out the pipes without success. There is no doubt that the floor of the children's dining room will have to be torn up to find the blockage, and portions of the floor will have to be relaid with new lumber. I cannot even make a guess at the cost of this repair, and as no names of plumbers are shown on the approved list for the district in which the school is situate, I would be pleased if the department would furnish the name of a plumber who could be asked to give an estimate on the cost of this work. There are also some minor repairs to be made to the heating system and to the water system.

Your obedient servant,

DR. HALL:

The following is an extract from a letter received in this office:

"Mr. Martin Jackson of Langruth was down to see me a few days ago. He has been putting down a well on his farm. Mr. W. Smith, a well-driller, did the work.

"Mr. Smith intimated to Mr. Jackson that there was some well casing in the Indian Reserve at Sandy Bay which was of no value as it had been put down in a dry well seven or eight years ago. He intimated that it would be no trouble to have that casing and Mr. Jackson pay what the Department felt should be paid.

"However, before getting permission to remove the casing, he removed the casing and put it down Mr. Jackson's well. Mr. Jackson was under the impression that he had received permission but subsequently it transpired that no permission had been given and I think the Priest at Sandy Bay laid information against Smith for stealing the pipe.

"The Mounted Police made a visit to the area and reported to the Indian Department what they had found. The pipe is at present on Mr. Martin Jackson's farm, down his well 80 feet of it and 20 feet lying on the surface.

"For your information I may say that the wholesale price for this pipe new is around 70¢ a foot. The pipe has been down in alkali ground where chemical action will no doubt have deteriorated the metal for many years and so it is up to Mr. Crerar to say how much a foot Mr. Jackson shall pay for this second-hand pipe.

"I shall be glad if you will take this matter up directly as these gentlemen are both rather worried."
MEMORANDUM

Will you kindly let me have a report, for the Minister's information, as to what action you would suggest should be taken with a view to selling this pipe to Mr. Jackson.

W.J.F. Pratt.
October 26th, 1956.

RESPECTFUL,

The Honorable The Superintendent General,

Referring to Mr. Scott's memorandum of October 23rd in reference to some well casing which was removed from the Sandy Bay School grounds without authority by Mr. Martin Johnson, or Mr. W. Smith, a well-driller, acting on his behalf, I would state that the disposition of government property such as this must be made through the Dominion Salvage Officer.

The only suggestion that I can offer now is that Mr. Johnson should submit a price for this casing and it will then be placed in the hands of the Dominion Salvage Officer for disposal. I do not see how we can place a price on the pipe but if a fair offer is made I think we might make a recommendation to Colonel Beer that it be accepted. We paid for this pipe ten years ago at the rate of $1.14 per foot.

I beg to refer to Department letter dated May 26th, file above noted, in connection with certain repairs to the boiler, Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, in which the name of Lye and Son, Limited was given as the firm to do this work.

I wrote to this firm on June 8th in reference to this work, and received a reply from them June 27th, in which they state "We will take care of this work at our earliest convenience." I allowed this matter to rest until September 24th, when I again wrote them, as the work should have been completed before the cold weather set in. They replied to my letter on October 14th, and I enclose a copy of their reply. The Burns and Company referred to in their letter was taken over by The Marshall Wells Co., Limited of Winnipeg, and I immediately got in touch with this firm asking them to furnish the repair. The Marshall Wells Company wrote back stating the John Inglis Company - the firm who made the furnace - was out of business, but enclosed a catalogue of the furnaces manufactured by this firm when in business, with the information that the parts could be purchased through them. I immediately transferred this information, with the catalogue, to Lye and Sons. This was forwarded on the 6th ultimo. Having received no reply I again wrote them, and today I am in receipt of their reply, which also is attached herewith.

Personally, I do not think it necessary to tear down the boiler. All that is required is a new flame sheet and minor repairs to several pipes. It will be necessary to tear down some of the brickwork to install the flame sheet, and I do not consider this a big job.

I feel that this firm has been very lax in attending to this work, as most of the inquiries were made from this office.

The Secretary,

"However, if you would prefer to turn the job over to one of the Hardwares there, it will be quite satisfactory to us".

Sir,

By Department letter of January 8th., file above noted, an amount of $60 was approved to purchase three washing machines, etc., for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. The three machines were purchased from the Marshall-Wells Company of Winnipeg at a cost of $37.55, and I am recently in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Principal asking that these machines be returned and one gasoline driven washer purchased in their place.

The Marshall-Wells Company will accept the return, and quote a price of approximately $109.50 for the gasoline driven machine. There is no doubt that the hand power machines are not suitable in a Residential School unless a power driven machine is provided for the heavy washing. This would be a supplementary unit to the hand washing machines they already have.

I request therefore, a further amount of $49.50, so that a power machine may be purchased.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, February 27, 1937.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, regarding the authority granted you for the purchase from a firm on the approved list of three (3) hand power washing machines and three (3) wringers for use at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

It is now noted that these three (3) machines were purchased and forwarded to the school but that the Principal is requesting that they be returned and a gasoline driven washer purchased in their place at an extra cost of $49.50 over that of the three hand power machines. In this connection, I would refer to your letter of January 5th, last, in which you stated that the Principal requested that hand power machines and wringers be supplied. The Principal should have definitely made up his mind as to his requirements before making his request. However, in view of your report that these hand power machines are not suitable for the heavy washing in a residential school, the Department approves of your arranging to have the three machines and wringers returned and a gasoline driven washer supplied in their place. It is noted that the cost will be, approximately, $109.50. There should be no expense to the Department in transportation charges for returning the three machines.

After the gasoline driven machine has been delivered at the school, you should obtain an account in triplicate, covering the cost, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Yours truly,

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Rev. Father Plourde and the Rev. Father Provincial called recently to discuss conditions at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. We, of course, realize that this school is poorly equipped and needs, not only equipment, but extensive repairs.

June 1, 1937.

Sir,

In reference to Department letter 126-9-5 dated December 7th last, I beg to advise that the brick work on the boiler at the Sandy Bay Residential School should be repaired at this time. In addition to the repairs that were necessary last year, the brick arches in the fire box also require repairing. The Reverend Principal suggested that I recommend the name of the Yates Company, Brandon, Manitoba to do this work. He claims this is a reliable firm which has done considerable work on boilers in various residential schools in the province.

The laundry boiler is in need of repairs. The brick work inside and out is breaking down, new plates are required, also repairs to various steam pipes and connections.

The main pipe and connection to two toilets is blocked. The school staff spent several days trying to remove the cause without success. From previous experience I judge the pipe to be corroded and will have to be replaced.

A number of similar repairs are needed for the heating system. Various pipes should be replaced and all radiator connections renewed. The school staff would do the radiator repairs if five dozen radiator connections were purchased.

In all probability repairs will be required to the brick work on the chimney and I beg to suggest that a boiler expert be sent in and an estimate obtained on the work required.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I was on the Sandy Bay Reserve this week and inspected the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

The Department is well aware of the condition of the building. A large portion of the building has never been re-painted since construction and the dormitory walls have never even been kalsomined. The school has been in operation over 30 years. Naturally the walls are dark and gloomy and the plaster needs repairing.

It would require a large expenditure to do the entire building, but for this year I would like authority to spend $250.00 for paint and kalsomine.

The kitchen cupboards are built against the wall and extend from the floor to the ceiling. These cupboards are over-run with rats and the walls eaten full of holes. New cupboards, lined with tin, should be provided. The lumber and material will cost approximately $150.00. The condition of the present cupboards is a disgrace and new ones should be provided.

The stair treads are, in many places, unsafe and lumber for new treads is required. I do not know the number of feet necessary but the expense would not be very high.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA,
Ont.

The furnace and plumbing need attention but I understand, Mr. Waite, the agent, has authority concerning this work.

The fire protection is poor and with the acetylene lighting plant, I can only picture the building as a fire trap. Dear Sir,

Re School at Marius.

Acting on your letter of August 18, we investigated the condition of the work therein mentioned.

(1) LAUNDRY BOILER.

Boiler is 30" Dia 8 ft long - 20-3" Tubes, Grates 49x30 inches. 20 lbs pressure used.

The Brickwork is in very bad condition, the whole of one side will have to be taken down and rebricked, and all the fire brick lining will have to be renewed, and a new cast iron Arch Plate installed.

We estimate the cost of this Brickwork at;-

ONE HUNDRED & FORTY EIGHT DOLLARS..........................$148.00

(2) The Grates on this Boiler are also badly warped and should be replaced, but we would recommend that they be replaced with grates only 36" long in place of the 49" now in. We suggest Herringbone pattern 4½ wide with grate rest to cost.........................................................$36.50

As a better grate for the Boiler, and you would still be able to burn cord wood with more economy.

(3) A great deal of the Steam & Water Piping over and around this Boiler will have to be renewed. All the Return Piping at the Boiler and the Return from the Coil in Dryer is badly corroded and just now is full of wooden plugs which are liable to blow out and cause damage.

The Return at the Boiler is full of mud and scale, and no means has been provided for getting it out.

There are several Radiators that were connected with this Boiler that have been broken and disconnected and should be repaired and put back.

New Discs should be put on all the Valves at the Boiler as none of them will hold tight.

A new Blow Down Valve is required, none is on now.

All the pipes to the Water column should be renewed.
and a Blow Down Valve be put in the bottom of Water Column to keep it clean.

The Hot Water Tank is set too low and as it has to come down to do the Brickwork, we would suggest that 2-0 longer supports be used under it when put back, so as to raise it two feet above the water line.

A new 6" Smoke Pipe to Agricultural Boiler is needed.

An automatic float air vent should be put on the return main at the Boiler, no means has been provided to eliminate the air.

The Boiler and Hot Water Tank also should be thoroughly cleaned, and the steam gauge refuses to work and should be replaced.

We estimate the cost of the above to be:

TWO HUNDRED & FORTY THREE DOLLARS & THIRTY FIVE CENTS....$243.35

HEATING BOILER.

Boiler is 60" Dia, 10ft long with 66-3" Tubes and is a four pass setting, (not a standard brick setting) which requires a good draft.

The centre dividing plate between the Tubes at the front of the Boiler, prevent the upper smoke doors closing properly. This of course checks the Draft which is never very good, and smoke comes out into the Basement. It will be necessary to use a cutting torch to fit this plate and also make new fasteners for doors.

The brick lining on one side is completely gone as well as the arch sides and cast iron arch plate. The other side will have to be taken down to make repairs also.

We estimate the cost of this work to be:

ONE HUNDRED & FORTY FIVE DOLLARS & SEVENTY FIVE CENTS....$145.75

HEATING BOILER.

The Water Column has never been provided with a
blow down valve, this should be remedied, as if this pipe becomes clogged, no one can tell where the water is in the Boiler.

The drip from the steam main enters the return above the water line, and there is no means of eliminating the air from the steam and return mains. This makes for a very erratic heating job and should be remedied.

All separate returns should enter the Boiler below the water line, here they do not.

It will likely be necessary to renew the return from the Boiler to the outside of brickwork. This could all be done together as well as cleaning the Boiler.

The estimated cost of this is:

ONE HUNDRED & TWENTY DOLLARS & SIXTY CENTS..................$120.60

RADIATORS.

Two Radiators have been disconnected and moved due to changes in the Chapel, these Rads will have to be reconnected with larger pipe due to the distance they are away from the tees in the Main.

The cost of this to be...........................................$29.25

The Soil Pipe from the Boys Dormitory has become full of urinal corrosion, due largely to a shortage of flushing. The pipe will have to be cut out and a section put in where it is found to be corroded and a cleanout put in.

The estimated cost of this is.................................$40.00

A 3" overflow installed in one of the three Attic Tanks and connected with the 4" vent stack with deep seal trap, could be installed for the sum of..........................$35.00

We would recommend that a new Chimney be built for the Heating Boiler and a new Breeching be installed as the one now in is inadequate to properly take care of the smoke from the Boiler. As far as we could find out without climbing to the top, the present Chimney is only 9x12. A new Chimney should be at
least 18x18 inside and 60 ft high, and could be built with new breeching for the sum of:

THREE HUNDRED & FIFTY FIVE DOLLARS..................$355.00

We humbly submit this request for your consideration.

These prices are based on Board and Lodgings for men being supplied by the School.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 126-9-5 dated September 11th, I would report that on October 1st I inspected, with Mr. Waite and Mr. Yates, the plumbing repair work at the Sandy Bay School.

The work is well along and when completed, about next Tuesday, should leave the heating and plumbing in good condition. The work has been well done and has entailed not only a large amount of labour but also considerable amount of new material. I would point out that some of the pipes renewed were filled with a hard, almost cement, substance and in some cases the opening left would not admit a pencil. Other pipes were so badly rusted that they broke when disconnected. This work only covers known weak spots; no doubt breaks will continue to occur as the water in use is very hard on any pipe or plumbing fixture.

The repair work outlined for the furnace has been completed and the Rev. Father admits it operates much better. The danger from fire has also been greatly reduced.

The chimney has been thoroughly examined and the men tell me there is no danger from fire. The type of furnace in use needs extra draft, and the chimney is lacking in size. However, it has served for many years and the draft has been improved by the repairs made to the brickwork of the furnace. A new chimney will not be erected.

I did however authorize two new closet bowls and new pipe leading from the two closets in the boys dormitory. Both the bowls and pipes were found to be cracked and the renewal meant considerable expense. The extra expense for material and labour will not exceed $65.00. I hope you approve of this expense.

Bills covering the work will be submitted to Mr. Waite and forwarded for payment.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir;

As you requested we proceeded to Sandy Bay to see what could be done with the leak in the Laundry boiler.

After removing some of the brickwork, we found a hole had been eaten through the side of the shell of the boiler, near the back lug, 2 ½" below the lug, and 2" from the lug toward the back of boiler. It will be necessary to have a boiler maker put a patch over this weak spot. It has apparently been caused by a leak from above, sometime in the past, there being no leak from above now. Likely from some of the pipes we removed during repairs this fall. The rest of the boiler seems to be in fair shape, but is getting old and Sandy Bay water is hard on steel.

I took the matter up with the boiler maker here immediately on my return, as I knew you would want to know the cost. As near as we can tell it will cost $75.00, including the trip today. If this is done the boiler should be good for two or three more years, but can tell you better after the boiler maker has gone over as much of the boiler as he can get at. However no guarantee can be given as to how long this boiler will last. This price also includes cutting out and replacing the necessary brickwork.

A new boiler of the same size and type, which, by the way, is the best for the work it has to do, would cost about $400.00, using the present casting and part of present brickwork.

As soon as you can, please let me know what to do, as the longer this job is left the harder it will be to get there by car. We had to shovel a lot of snow to get through today.

Yours respectfully,

Yates, Neale & Co.

Sir,

On the 18th inst., I received a phone call from Mr. Inspector Hamilton in which he quoted a telegram he received from Reverend O. Chagnon, Principal, Sandy Bay Indian Residential School reading as follows:

"Laundry boiler shell bursted. Send steamfitter at once."

I immediately got in touch with Yates, Neale & Co., of Brandon and Mr. Yates advised that he would look into this immediately. The attached letter is his report on the break.

Mr. J. Waite,

Dear Sir,

Re Sandy Bay Laundry Boiler.

Acting on your letter of Nov 25/37, we repaired the Laundry Boiler at Sandy Bay.

In order to put on the patch it was necessary to cut in a Hand Hole above the repair to insert bolts from the inside.

The Boiler Maker, Mr. Hosie, at one time a Provincial Boiler Inspector, reports that the Boiler is badly pitted from the inside and is liable to blow through at any time. It is a condition that makes it almost impossible to predict how long the Boiler will last.

It is this man's opinion that the Boiler should be replaced next summer. It will not be necessary to replace any Boiler Castings, just the Steel Boiler and that part of the brickwork which is over the lugs of the Boiler.

We are enclosing the account for the amount of the repairs.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 8, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, in which you report that it will probably be necessary to replace the laundry boiler at the Sandy Bay Residential School in the near future. The letter from Mr. Yates states that a steel boiler will be required.

As all purchases are now made by the Purchasing Agent, it is necessary to have complete information regarding any article required. You should therefore let me know the height and diameter of the steel boiler that would be necessary for this school, also any other information that will assist us in placing an order.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER,

In response to the request contained in Mr. Jackson's memorandum of January 16th, I am submitting herewith a report on the educational facilities and general social and economic conditions at the Sandy Bay reserve, province of Manitoba.

The Sandy Bay reserve consists of an area of approximately 12,000 acres and borders on the west shore of Lake Manitoba, just east of the Canadian National line which runs from the city of Portage la Prairie to Alonza. This reserve has a population of 480 Indians and a school population of approximately 160. There is a pupil enrolment at the Sandy Bay Residential School on this reserve of 75. A per capita grant of $185.00 is paid by the Department. It would appear that no provision has been made on the reserve for the education of the additional 85 pupils. It is difficult to determine from the records here the exact date of the establishment of the residential school. It was taken over by the Department in the year 1936 and it is estimated that the building is between 45 and 50 years old.

In the year 1934-35 I recommended the construction of a day school on this reserve, and this recommendation was approved by the Superintendent General. An amount necessary for the construction of this school was placed in the 1934-35 estimates, but the construction of the school was not proceeded with.

This Band of Indians is in many respects one of the most backward of any band in the Dominion. In the year 1928-29 an attempt was made to promote a housing programme -
programme on the reserve and a liberal amount was included in the estimates of that year for that purpose. Only a few of the Indians, however, took advantage of the offer and the outcome of the undertaking was wholly unsatisfactory.

Dr. M. R. Elliott, Provincial Epidemiologist, Province of Manitoba, in a special report dated December 8, 1937, on the sanitary conditions on this reserve, states:

"We would consider, from this investigation, that a definite focus of infection - whether it be from the water supply or carriers - exists on this reserve and that existing sanitary conditions are favourable for a much greater spread of disease in the spring months, if not at present. Toilet facilities do not exist and the houses, which consist of one-storey log shacks, are hopelessly overcrowded."

It should be borne in mind that the Sandy Bay reserve does not provide such scope for development. Part of the area is swampy and the greater part of it covered by poplar and brush. While some open spaces could be farmed by the diligently inclined, the major portion of the top soil is shallow, inclined to be alkali and in part stony. The areas surrounding the reserve are of similar character and only a few settlers live on lands adjoining the reserve boundaries. The limited agricultural possibilities at this reserve may in part explain the present backward condition of the Band. It is significant, however, that the Indian inspectors who have visited and reported on the reserve from time to time express the view that this Band of Indians appear to be more restless and more nomadic in their habits than the majority of Indian bands, even in the western provinces. Inspector Hamilton, in a report dated October 15, 1935, states:

"I am informed that these Indians attend town fairs and sport days all over the southern portion of Manitoba and are often two or three hundred miles away from their homes."

The existing conditions are sufficiently disturbing to justify a very thorough investigation of the
educational needs of these Indians.

Indian day schools were wholly impracticable at the time the Sandy Bay Residential School was established. The Indians at that time were engaged wholly in hunting, fishing and trapping. They had not at that date acquired even an elementary knowledge of agriculture. They lived a primitive, nomadic existence and supported themselves from the fur and game resources of the country. A residential school was the only institution, at that time, that could possibly meet the needs of such a band. The utmost credit is due to the early missionaries for the self-sacrificing attempts they made to educate and Christianize the Indians of this country. It is not necessary to question either the loyalty or devotion of the members of the teaching staff of this or any other residential school. The principals of these schools have been instructed to follow provincial curricula - curricula which, in my judgment, are altogether too academic and abstract to meet the needs of our Indian population. It is worthy of note that there is in evidence today a tendency on the part of public school authorities to place steadily increasing emphasis upon manual training, vocational instruction and courses of study designed to equip the average pupil for the tasks he must undertake after his departure from school.

Our Welfare programme, for which provision was made in the estimates of last year, is designed to re-establish our Indian population on a self-supporting basis. The purchase of farming equipment, the construction of homes, the clearing of land and the purchase of seed has substantially improved conditions on a number of reserves in Western Canada, and it is our hope that this programme can be further extended. The residential school, in relieving Indian parents of the responsibility for the care of their children, appears to have a tendency to encourage them in their nomadic and roaming habits. We have instances of land cultivated and seeded in the spring and abandoned later by Indians who refused to remain on their reserve to harvest the crop. On the other hand, where parents have had to accept responsibility for the care and welfare of their children and where provision has been
made for the education of these children at Indian day schools, the Indians appear to be more willing to cultivate reserve lands, take a greater interest in agriculture and consequently tend to become more self-supporting. My recommendation of 1934-35, that an Indian day school be established on the Sandy Bay reserve, was prompted by the conviction that an up-to-date day school would have a tendency to encourage the Indians of this reserve to become less nomadic in their habits and more interested in the development of their lands.

A fully equipped fire-proof residential school, with accommodation for 165 pupils, would cost approximately $150,000. I cannot, in view of conditions at present existing on this reserve, recommend that such an institution be established.

I have already intimated that the resources of this reserve are limited and the lands submarginal. There is nothing on the file to indicate that these resources are capable of supporting an Indian population equal to the one at present on the reserve. A survey of the lands available, with satisfactory soil tests, should be undertaken at an early date. I am convinced that a capable investigator would discover that the Sandy Bay reserve is only capable of supporting a comparatively small Indian population, the members of which might earn a living by cattle raising, fishing and the cultivation of small gardens, and that additional resources should be secured for these Indians, particularly the younger members of the Band, in another section of the province.

May I recommend, therefore, the establishment on this reserve of a fully equipped two-room day school, with full basement accommodation, suitable for manual training, carpentry work, sewing, fruit preserving, etc. Living accommodation for the members of the staff should be provided at the school. A suitable area of land adjoining the school should also be selected, with a farmer manager in charge, capable of giving instruction to the pupils. This farm could easily become a supply station for the school and provide the
vegetables and meat necessary for midday meals, which have become so beneficial and popular at other day schools throughout the Dominion. A school such as this would provide accommodation for approximately 80 pupils, and, in addition, would provide a community centre where adult education could be provided in the evenings and where short courses relating to poultry keeping, live stock bee-keeping, health and sanitation could be organized from time to time.

I feel confident that Archbishop Simnett, who is deeply interested in the welfare of Indians, would be glad to co-operate with the Department in the promotion of any programme designed to improve conditions on this reserve.

Director.

Extract from letter dated July 6, 1938, received from Dr. J. J. WALL.

It is with respect to the fire hazard at night in four of our Schools. They are Sandy Bay, Man., Round Lake and Cowessess of Broadview, Sask., and lastly and especially Hobbema, Alta. In any of these institutions, should I sleep there, I always have the flash-light, overcoat, socks and gloves available and prepared for a sudden dive into the winter night. This fear in these four places certainly has not become an obsession but it has started to bother my conscience.

I know how foolish it would be in these hard times to imagine that funds are available for proper reconstruction. But is it not possible to get proper escape apparatus installed. Every second for evacuation time must be conserved. I am not frightened so much of the flames at night but I am fearful of the superheated gases developing and flooding the halls. Only a partial lung-ful of this and a person is out. All the fire fighting equipment possible will not avail such a case. That was my experience years ago at the Royal Victoria in Montreal when we had that terrible movie fire which took so many children. It was not the flames, as I recollect, none were even scorched.

My belief is that this problem can be solved in preparing proper escapes. Iced poles of iron, narrow snow or ice filled metal stairs on the outside possibly open to a wall of flames from some window it passes will only add to the panic at night. Poor lighting over these meager affairs will not assist.

The panic in the children when a real fire does break will be stupendous. The stoical Indian in such case is a figment on the part of certain popular authors.

Dont be sore at me, Phil., as I am prepared to lay a two to one bet up to 100 bucks that in case of such an eventuality in any of the four, happening in winter between ten at night and four in the morning, the mortality will exceed...
thirty per cent.

The ideal thing would be an inspection of each by an officer, like the Chief of the Montreal brigade, who has had plenty of experience dealing with such institutional hazards. His first consideration would be to figure the route the fire and gases would take so that adequate methods and routes of escape can be instituted. Steel fire doors would undoubtedly be installed on each floor above the first. Steel tower-like escapes as on the Kent Street School at Ottawa would replace at strategic points the old dangerous poles and narrow stairs. Lists of pupils to utilize each escape would be posted at all times and each child's name checked from list as it passes by a responsible guardian. Many of the children otherwise, in the event of a genuine alarm will, if not watched, take refuge in a clothes closet or under its bed.

Night watchman was a step in the right direction but much can happen in the winter when he is penching in the outbuildings and barn and the time he returns to the school.

Much as I hate to bring your attention to this whole question in these four places, please understand it is not done so with any sense of butting in. It is for these poor kiddies sake, many of whom one becomes attached in his duties. In case also, should any catastrophe arise, we all shall be scourged properly at any investigation especially at the hands of politically conscious lawyers who cynically will give little credit to those who really and truly have the fullest interests of these tots at heart.
Ottawa, July 16, 1938.

Memorandum:

Dr. H. W. McGill,

Your memorandum of the 14th instant, re the purchase of material for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, has been received and referred to the Purchasing Agent to secure prices on the materials. However, before this can be done I should like to direct your attention to the evidently careless manner in which these requisitions have been prepared.

Materials for Granary and Barn:

100 finishing nails, 2";
100 finishing nails, 2½".
Does this mean 100 lbs. of each?

100 lbs., 3" nails;
1 keg, 3" nails.
Is this a duplication?

100 lbs. 2½" nails;
2 kegs, 2½" nails.
Are these quantities duplicated; if not, why does the requisition not state '3 kegs, 2½" nails.'

8,000 Shingles.
Shingles, to the best of my knowledge, are always ordered by the bundle or square, four bundles being required for one square. We have no knowledge of the number of shingles in a bundle.

900 ft. Roofing.
It is not understood whether this means 'Ready Roofing', or 900 sq.ft. of sheeting. If it means the former the requisition should state the number of ply.
I realize that this requisition may have been received in just this form from the Principal of the School, but, if so, it should have been referred back to him for proper descriptions, or corrected in your own office.

Chief Executive Assistant.
Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to the order for materials for the Sandy Bay Residential School, our Purchasing Agent has taken exception to the manner in which we requested certain articles. I refer to the following and give the Purchasing Agent's comments:

1. 8,000 shingles - "Shingles, to the best of my knowledge, are always ordered by the bundle or square, four bundles being required for one square. We have no knowledge of the number of shingles in a bundle."

2. 900 ft. Roofing - "It is not understood whether this means 'Ready Roofing', or 900 sq. ft. of sheeting. If it means the former the requisition should state the number of ply."

Please let me have the necessary information in connection with the above two items.

In one place on the requisition there is a request for 100 lbs. 3" nails and in another place one keg 3" nails. As there are 100 lbs. in each keg, was this a duplication or do they require two kegs of 3" nails?

I find, also, a request for 100 lbs. 2½" nails and two kegs of 2½" nails. Is this a duplication or do they require three kegs of 2½" nails?

I should appreciate very much receiving an immediate reply.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I have yours of July 22 re materials for Sandy Bay:

1. The following definition of "shingles" may be found in Rose's Handbook of Useful Information:
   "Shingles are usually 16 inches long, and a bundle of shingles is 20 inches wide, and contains 24 courses in the thickness at each end; hence, a bundle of shingles will lay one course 80 feet long. When shingles are exposed 4 inches to the weather, 1000 will cover 107 square feet; 4 1-2 inches, 120 square feet; 5 inches, 132 square feet; 6 inches, 150 square feet."

Father Chagnon, therefore, had in mind to order a quantity sufficient to cover about 850 square feet.

2. The 900 ft. of roofing must be interpreted to mean 900 board feet or what is commonly known in the lumber business as "roofing boards." All lumber dealers will understand this expression.

The quantity of nails specified in the list that I left with you and which was prepared by Father Chagnon includes two barrels of 3" nails and three kegs of 2 1-2" nails. This quantity of nails may seem rather large, but I understand that a large part of this order will be used to re-nail the siding on most of the building.

As the season is far advanced, will you be good enough to urge that the purchase of these materials be done without any further delay.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hosy:

The water supply at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential school has been quite unsatisfactory for the past five or six years. Could not something be done to improve conditions now existing.

I would suggest that you ask your engineer to make a report on this problem and that he be asked to suggest what could be done to install inadequate water system.

Some six years ago, the Department supplied a truck equipped with a large tank. This truck has been used ever since to haul water from the lake, a distance of about three miles to the school. If no better system can be found, I would suggest that a cistern of sufficient size be built and that pressure tanks be installed so that in case of fire there would be at least some kind of protection for the children and staff of the school. I am informed that the cistern now in use was poorly constructed, and cannot hold a sufficient quantity of water. The system suggested for St-Philip's school if put in operation at Sandy Bay would be much better than the one now in use.

At my suggestion, the principal early this month had a well twelve feet deep dug on the shores of the lake about 200 feet from the edge of the water. From information which I have received today, it would seem that the water from the lake seeps through the sand into this well. If this could be verified, it might be possible to pipe the water from this well to the school. I understand that a system of this kind was installed at the Fort Qu'Appelle hospital and is proving very satisfactory.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I desire to refer to our purchase requisition dated November 30, 1938 for 7 tires for the Chevrolet truck at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

During the latter part of 1934 the water supply from the well at the Sandy Bay Residential School which had been gradually diminishing ceased completely. Although the possibility of securing water by digging another well was carefully considered this procedure was rejected as we could obtain no assurance that there was any likelihood of obtaining water. The only other alternative was to expend an amount of $25,000.00 in piping water from Lake Manitoba, a distance of approximately 2 miles. As no funds were available for this purpose no action was taken on this recommendation.

In order to supply water the Department purchased a Chevrolet truck in January, 1935. This truck is equipped with a tank, and water is transported from Lake Manitoba to the school at regular intervals.

Since supplying the truck the Department has not paid any cost for its maintenance or its operation as these expenses have been borne by the school management.

A recent letter received from the school management stated that new tires were required for the truck and on writing to the Indian Agent he recommended that 7 tires be supplied.
You will note that this truck is used only for the transportation of water from the lake to the school. I consider that it is reasonable for the Department to supply new tires and it would, therefore, be appreciated if you would arrange for the immediate purchase of the tires requested on purchase requisition of November 30.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School dated November 29, 1938:

The dormitories were all well aired and spotlessly clean. The beds were neatly made but the mattresses are very poor - in fact 60% of the beds are fitted with straw ticks. I would recommend 36 mattresses for the girls and 24 for the boys.

The old gas plant is still operated for lighting purposes. This is located in the carpenter shop which adjoins the furnace room. I have always been very nervous concerning this lighting equipment and would strongly recommend that it be discarded and replaced by an electric lighting plant. I trust this matter will receive favourable consideration.

The boiler of the main heating plant is at present in fair condition although I am informed that the boiler inspector is of the opinion it will not pass another inspection. The boiler is old and, I have no doubt, it will be necessary to make a replacement soon.

The reception room on the main floor is 10 x 16. This room is in constant use by the Rev. Principal and other members of the staff. I would recommend the floor be covered with inlaid linoleum. It would be more easily cleaned and much more cheerful than a bare floor.

The kitchen is well kept. The hot water tank needs to be renewed. This tank is 16" across and 4 ft. 9" high. A new tank is urgently needed.

The laundry is well equipped except that there is no extractor (tumbler type). They have no way to get the water from the clothes, except with the hand wringer. If possible, an extractor should be provided.

(Sgd.) A. G. Hamilton,

February 13, 1939

Sir,

The Sandy Bay Indian Residential School is being wired for electric light. The capacity of the plant, I am informed, is 6000 watts. A temporary wiring is being installed at present in a number of rooms and the permanent installation will be carried out when certain improvements are made to the building. Under the present arrangement wiring for the light will be dropped from the ceiling which is antiquated system, and I beg to suggest that daylight units be furnished. The cost of each unit would be in the neighbourhood of $1.50 and 50 would be required. The daylight unit would be out of reach of the children, give more diffused light, easier on the children's eyesight and less wiring would be required. The system would also affect a saving in bulbs over a period of time as there is always a danger of hanging bulbs being broken.

Respectfully submitted,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Water Supply System Sandy Bay Residential School,
Amaranth, Manitoba.

As per your instructions, I have visited the above named school for the purpose of making an investigation of the existing water system, and I have the following to report in this connection:

My first visit to the school was made early in January, and during that trip I was fortunate enough to meet a member of the Catholic Church who was able to give me considerable information regarding the purpose of the request for the investigation of the system. He also advised me of the existence of the Interior, in 1934, and of which report I advised you, in my wire of January 6th, 1939. I immediately got in touch with Mr. Gow, and he very kindly forwarded me his office copy of the report, which I carefully examined, and then returned to him.

As previously advised in my wire, I am of the opinion that Mr. Gow's report covers the situation, under consideration, very thoroughly indeed, and the recommendations made, are, in my estimation, such, that the report should be acted upon in its entirety.

With reference to the instructions contained in your wire, regarding the suggested seepage sump, on the bank of Lake Manitoba, to be used as an intake for the proposed system, I may say that I have had sufficient work carried out on this proposed project to justify an opinion as to its feasibility in this particular locality, and the following is a detail of this work, together with the conclusions arrived at:

At a point on the bank of Lake Manitoba, corresponding approximately to Sta. 1 00 on Plate #2 of Mr. Gow's report, I had a hole dug to a depth of 5'-6", and the infiltration to this hole, or well, was carefully noted. The results as far as seepage was concerned were quite satisfactory; water bearing soil being encountered at the depth of 5' and continuing to the full depth of the hole. The infiltration was greatest from ......
greatest from the lake, or North side of the excavation, although we had a fairly steady flow from the South side also, this water appearing to flow from the swampy ground, indicated on Mr. Gow's plan, between Sta. 4700 and 2600.

Regarding the soils encountered in the excavation, these consisted of peaty muck to a depth of 5', 2' above and to the full depth of the hole. The water which resulted from the infiltration had a good color, and while slightly salty to the taste was quite palatable. We procured two samples of water, one from the excavated well and one from Lake Manitoba, the purpose of the two samples being, to try and determine whether the water in the well was a result of infiltration from the lake, or from the swampy ground. The following results of having this water analyzed would seem to prove that the water in the well was a result of seepage from the swampy ground:

Extract of Report, made by the Department of National Health, Winnipeg, Manitoba, on two water samples.

| Sample | Bacterial Colon Plate Count |
|--------|-----------------------------|
| Sample #1 (from lake) | Negative 300 |
| Sample #2 (from well) | Positive 2000 |

Remarks:- There would appear to be no infiltration from the lake to the well.

From the foregoing, it would appear that there is no purpose continuing along this line of investigation, as the difficulties that would have to be overcome, to protest such a source of supply from contamination, would, no doubt, outweigh any financial saving which would result from the avoidance of the construction of the intake proposed by Mr. Gow, that is of course, if sufficient water could be procured by such a method, for the proposed system.

In reference to your request for information on the wells in the vicinity of the school, and the feasibility of securing the required supply, by drilling a deep well, I may say that I am of the opinion that it would not be advisable to make any attempt to procure water for this purpose, by this method. My reason for being so definite in this regard is a result of a careful study of the situation, in which study I was fortunate enough to be able to procure the services of the driller of all the wells on the Indian Reserve in question, also innumerable other wells in that part of the province. Mr. Smith, the name of the driller referred to, informs me that from his experience in drilling in that part of the country he believes that, as far as quantity is concerned, the matter is a foregone conclusion, but the quality of the water would not be of the standard required. Since these statements are amply supported by actual wells in operation in this area, I have no hesitation in recommending that the matter of drilling for water be dropped, and this of course results in having to depend on Lake Manitoba for the required supply, which to me appears the only logical source of water supply for any system that may be installed at this point.
It is noted in Mr. Gow's report that some question had arisen as to the advisability of the installation of an expensive water system at the school in question, owing to the fact that the school buildings are very old, and I also understand that some proposal had been made to change the site of the school. Since this opinion may have had some bearing on previous reports, I may say that at this time the matter of enlarging the school is under definite consideration, and from my observations I would say that the matter of an adequate water supply for such a large institution is of the greatest importance at the earliest possible date, and as mentioned earlier in this report I would suggest that Mr. Gow's recommendations be carried out in this connection.

Faithfully yours,

(sgd.) J.A. Atkinson,
Junior Engineer.
March 3, 1929.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Water Supply, Sandy Bay Residential School, Amaranth, Manitoba.

In further reference to your memorandum of November 15th last transmitting a copy of a memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs regarding the above matter I might say that in accordance with your instructions, Mr. J. H. Atkinson of our Engineering staff was requested to visit the school and look carefully into the question of an adequate water supply. A report on a proposed water supply system at this point was made by Mr. D. B. Gow of the Water and Power Bureau, dated September 5th, 1928, and was referred to in a preliminary report wired in by Mr. Atkinson. Further instructions were sent the latter to supplement the Gow report with additional information covering depth of wells near the school at present and possibility of further drilling.

Mr. Atkinson's report has now been received and a copy is attached hereto for your information. You will note he is of the opinion that the Gow report covers the situation very thoroughly and that in his estimation the recommendations made are such that the report should be acted upon in its entirety. The system proposed by Mr. Gow consists of an intake line extending from a point 630 feet beyond water's edge of Lake Manitoba to a concrete lined well, a total distance of approximately 3,500 feet. A pump is to be located at this well, and a main supply line from this point to a reservoir in the immediate vicinity of the school. The total length of this supply line is approximately 6,450 feet. A second pumping outfit would be installed at the school to pump water to reservoir tanks already in place in the attic. It is proposed to utilize the present distribution system, replacing such piping as is necessary and adding whatever piping is required for the additional services it is proposed to install. A summary of Mr. Gow's estimates of costs of the above proposals is as follows:

(a) Intake - $7,320.00
(b) Pipe Line - $3,470.00
(c) Pumping System - $1,900.00
(d) Distributing System - $3,965.00
Contingencies Supervision, etc. $2,116.50
Hauling - Railway to job $350.00

Total estimated cost --------- $22,821.50

J. H. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
In regard to the amount shown for the distribution system, I might say that Mr. Gow recommended the installation of a hot water supply boiler and a high pressure steam boiler, which have been included in this item at an estimated cost of $665.00.

With regard to the further information requested from Mr. Atkinson covering possibility of using wells, you will note he is of the opinion that it would not be advisable to make any attempt to procure water by this method. He reports that from information received and from his personal observation, while sufficient quantity of water can be got, the quality would not be of the standard required, and he therefore recommends that the matter of drilling for water be dropped. This, of course, results in having to depend on Lake Manitoba for the required supply.

In view of all the circumstances, I concur in Mr. Atkinson's suggestion that Mr. Gow's recommendation as outlined in his report be carried out, and would further suggest that the Director of Indian Affairs be so advised in order that he may be in a position to provide for the necessary funds for this work in the Supplementary Estimates if it is his intention to have the work carried out during the coming season.

Respectfully submitted,

T. F. H.
March 3, 1939.

He reports that from information received and from his personal observation, while sufficient quantity of water can be got, the quality would not be of the standard required, and he therefore recommends that the matter of drilling for water be dropped. This, of course, results in having to depend on Lake Manitoba for the required supply.

In view of all the circumstances, I concur in Mr. Atkinson's suggestion that Mr. Gow's recommendations as outlined in his report be carried out, and would further suggest that the Director of Indian Affairs be so advised in order that he may be in a position to provide for the necessary funds for this work in the Supplementary Estimates if it is his intention to have the work carried out during the coming season.

To His Excellency Mgr. A.A. Sinnott,
Archbishop of Winnipeg, Man.

Excellency and Dear Monsignor,

I have received your letter of the 31st of March concerning our water supply system at our school. I wish first to thank you very heartily for your interest in our behalf.

With regard to the project of transferring our Indians into another Reserve, my firm conviction is that they would never consent to leave Sandy Bay. If there should be the necessity of enlarging the reserve, the best mean would be to grant them more space along the shore of Lake Manitoba.

As to the enlargement of our school, providing two fire-proof dormitories, I sincerely hope that the Department of Indian Affairs shall not remit the project for another year. In the present conditions, we are greatly exposed to a complete fire destruction, so I would take the liberty of asking your Excellency to do your utmost towards the Honourable Mr. Crerar to have this enlargement done this summer.

As to the water supply, Mr. Gow's project of providing the water from the lake, would be indeed too costly, I would prefer to continue carting the water from the lake, as we have done from the last fifteen years rather than to hear that the enlargement has been postponed for another year.

I have learned with pleasure that the Department of Indian Affairs, will ask the engineer Mr. Atkinson informations on the possibility of barring a brook near the school so as to store up the water in spring. I believe that this project could be made at a very low cost and will provide abundantly the water necessary for the laundry and sewer purposes. My experience since thirty years at Sandy Bay allows me to ascertain that the water coming from this brook in spring would be more than enough, outside of the drinking and cooking purposes, to provide for all the other needs of the school.

With deep respect, I remain, Excellency, yours in Christ and in Mary Immaculate.

(Sgd) O. Chagnon, O.M.I.
Winnipeg, Man.,
April 7th, 1939.

Hon. T.A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

My dear Mr. Crerar,

I enclose the answer which I received from the Fathers at Sandy Bay Indian Reserve. I think it solves the difficulty. Father Chagnon, who signs the letter, is an old man who is very sound in his judgment and has had a long experience. When he says that the Indians would not leave Sandy Bay, I cannot but believe him. No doubt some would go, but there would be no use in creating another Reserve and have to keep Sandy Bay at the same time. Better to procure some land North of the present Reserve.

As to the water supply, I am persuaded that it is better to forget the recommendations of Mr. Gow. It is an unnecessary expense. I know that there is a creek which flows by the School and in which there is considerable water in the spring-time. Were this creek dammed, enough water could be secured for laundry and sewer purposes. With the wells and water hauled from the Lake, there would be no shortage for drinking and cooking.

My conclusion is to go ahead with the two new fire-proof additions and forget about the water difficulty. That too is the conclusion of the Fathers in charge of the School. You will have done everything that I could ask of you and I would be thoroughly satisfied. The additions are necessary and they will make the institution such as to satisfy the needs of the place for many years to come. I hope, therefore, that there will not be further delay.

I enclose Mr. Gow's Report as requested.

With kindest personal regards,

Very faithfully yours,

(Sgd) Alfred A. Sinnett,
Archbishop of Winnipeg.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I beg to acknowledge yours of May 8th regarding account of Dominion Electric Co., Ltd. of Winnipeg for electrical goods supplied to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School on January 27, 1939.

I took it upon myself to place this order directly because the goods were immediately needed for the installation of the electric plant at the Sandy Bay school. The engineer was on the premises and had I not placed this order immediately, he would have had to be brought back to Winnipeg and sent back again on receipt of the material needed for the complete installation of the plant. This would have meant an expense of at least $30.00.

I secured three bids; firstly, from the Dominion Electric Co.; secondly, from Marshall-Wells of Winnipeg; and thirdly, from Ashdown Hardware Co., Ltd. I placed the order with the Dominion Electric Co. because their price was the lowest. I am enclosing for your information the three bids mentioned above.

Hoping that this will help you to put the account through, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Wasagaming, Man., May 10th, 1939.

Dear Sir,

Re - Sandy Bay Indian School Water Supply.

As instructed by you in your wire in connection with the above matter I proceeded to the Sandy Bay School and examined the area for the purpose of considering the construction of a dam for impounding a water supply for the school, and in this connection I have today forwarded to you a sketch plan of the area together with a suggested layout of the proposed dam.

As you will note from the plan, we suggest the construction of an earth dam at a point on the plan referred to as Station 6+00. This point is on a dry water course to the west of the school and is, I believe, a very good site for such a construction.

In approaching this problem I considered the following factors:

1. Source of supply
2. Drainage area or watershed
3. Quantity of water required
4. Evaporation, percolation and absorption
5. Protection of winter supply in dam
6. Type of dam and cost of proposed work

(1) Regarding the source of supply I may say that a very well defined water course extending in a westerly direction for approximately one mile drains an area estimated at about six square miles. This area is comparatively flat country and is quite heavily covered with brush. The stream bed referred to indicates that there has been a considerable flow at one time, but there was little evidence of flow recently. However, we were advised by the officials at the school that after heavy rainfall the stream will flow for several days at a depth of about one foot, depending of course, upon the duration and intensity of the storm.

As mentioned above, the stream drains a piece of land about three miles by two miles. This area appears to me to be very definite in length since it terminates at the highway, which is the highest of land in a westerly direction. This height of land has constructed drainage ditches through it draining the land to the west of the highway into Lake Manitoba, to which lake the dry creek bed upon which the proposed dam would be constructed, also drains. This item is of particular interest in that I believe one of these ditches might be connected with the creek bed, if and when required, without much cost. This matter was not, however, gone into by me other than to discuss its feasibility.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

(2) Drainage area or watershed

The proposed reservoir will be entirely dependent on rainfall and snowfall, and with regard to the latter our examination of the area was at the time of year when the runoff from snow should have been noticeable but we saw practically no indication of water throughout the whole of the drainage area. We were, however, advised that two weeks before, that is, about the 24th of March, there had been a considerable flow in the stream had lasting about seven days. From reports generally in the district the conditions this spring were extraordinary owing to the lightness of the snow, etc.

(3),(4),(5) The matter of quantity was considered and was based on the following:-

(a) Reported requirements
(b) Evaporation, seepage, percolation
(c) Ice coverage in reservoir

In connection with the reported requirements it was definitely stated that 600 gallons per day would be ample. We have allowed for 1,000 gallons per day and this would amount to 365,000 gallons per year. All other factors combined would not, we assume, equal this amount, but the capacity of the reservoir proposed is such that we believe that all factors, whatever they may be, will be adequately taken care of, if the reservoir is filled to capacity. The location of the dam was chosen because it reduces the length of the dam required and also it reduces the amount of excavation which we consider is necessary to give the depth of water which will allow for the thirty-six inches of ice which will result in the winter, together with the body of water required for the period of four months when the ice is on the reservoir. We believe also that the depth of the reservoir proposed will be beneficial from an evaporation standpoint.

(6) The type of dam proposed is of the earth type with no core wall or reinforcing of any kind other than the proposed minimum twenty-five percent clay well tamped in place under the topsoil. The soil in the vicinity of the dam is a sandy loam to a depth of about four feet where heavy clay loam or hardpan is encountered. Regarding the cost of this proposed work the following is a detail of the items of cost:-

Excavation within reservoir area 4,172 cubic yds. Excavated by drag scraper methods and used in the construction of the dam and the balance wasted in the vicinity of the dam site. We estimate the cost per yard will be .20¢ making a total cost of $834.40.

A one yard dragline which I believe is available in Manitoba could be used to advantage on this work and would reduce the cost considerably, as this machine will remove approximately 500 cubic yards of material per ten hour day, with a fuel consumption of two gallons of fuel. However, this matter can be gone into if it is necessary.
The dam would be constructed by the placing of the above mentioned cut material, care being taken to compact the mass by proper dumping and rolling. The removal of the house and debris generally, within the reservoir area will cost approximately $100.00.

Regarding the connection of the water supply to the school, this will be carried out by the installation of a two inch main from the dam to a sump at the windmill site by gravity and will be pumped to the school system by windmill. A summary of the total cost is as follows:

I have, however, given this matter considerable consideration and believe that the estimate and detail as submitted is a sound estimate of the proposed work. Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

With reference to your memorandum of April 6th last regarding the possibility of securing a water supply for the Sandy Bay School at Amaranth, Manitoba, for domestic purposes except drinking by impounding water in an adjacent creek bed, attached hereto is a copy of a report on the proposal prepared by Mr. Atkinson.

The following points in Mr. Atkinson's report should be noted:

(1) Source of supply and quantity available. There is a well defined watercourse with a drainage area of about six square miles. While there was indication of a considerable flow at one time, there was little evidence of any recent flow and there was at the time of the inspection no indication of water throughout the whole drainage area. It was reported, however, that about two weeks previously, March 24th, there had been a considerable flow lasting seven days.

(2) Requirements of the School. These are stated to be 600 gals. per day but Mr. Atkinson based his estimate on 1,000 gals. per day or 365,000 gals. per year.

(3) Estimated cost of impounding works. Mr. Atkinson states that provision could be made for impounding the required amount after making due allowances for losses due to seepage, evaporation and ice, at a cost of $1,680.00. This includes excavation of reservoir, construction of dam, clearing up site and piping water to buildings. It would appear from the plan submitted that a more adequate spillway should be provided, thus adding possibly $150.00 to the total cost.

In a report on this project in 1932 submitted by Mr. Gow, the school authorities estimated their requirements at 2,000 gals. per day or 1,100,000 gals. per year. Mr. Gow stated that in comparison with other schools this consumption was conservative and estimated that if an adequate supply were available the consumption would be nearer 5,000 gals. per day. Basing his assumption on 4,000 gals. per day he estimated that the cost of providing an 8 months supply would be $1,800.00 or a 12 months supply $7,850.00. These costs did not include piping to the school nor any allowances for engineering, supervision or contingencies.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Mr. Gow stated further that in his opinion such a source of water supply is unsuited for drinking or cooking purposes and should not be so utilized. It will be subject to contamination; vegetable growth will develop in the stagnant pool, giving the water a disagreeable taste and offensive odor and in all probability the Department would be called upon later to provide treatment to remedy these conditions.

It would appear from the foregoing that the information supplied to the Chief Executive Assistant by the Principal of the School as noted in your memorandum of April 4th last - that the creek flowed throughout the year - is erroneous. It should also be noted that Mr. Gow's wire of April 5th last quoted in our memorandum of that date stated that run-off conditions since 1932 had been such that little consideration should be given to the scheme except possibly for summer stock watering in some years.

In the circumstances and in view of the fact that nothing but a safe water supply should be provided for an institution of this nature, I would refer you to my memorandum of March 3rd last submitting a report by Mr. Atkinson in which he concurred in Mr. Gow's findings as reported by the latter under date of September 5th, 1934.

Respectfully submitted,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Sandy Bay Indian School, water supply.

With reference to the above, I am forwarding a copy of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer with a copy of a report submitted by Engineer Atkinson covering his recent inspection of a possible water supply at Sandy Bay Indian School. The report indicates that the water supply, which might be obtained by damming the water course, would be very doubtful as to quantity and quality of the water.

Under these circumstances it is recommended by our Engineers that instead of expending funds on a scheme of such an uncertain nature steps should be taken to obtain the water supply for this school from Lake Winnipeg as recommended formerly.

Dear Sir:

On instructions from the above organization, I am seeking some information as regards the extension to the Indian School at Sandy Bay, Manitoba, the Supervising contractor being Mr P. Desrosiers, Contractor of St Boniface, Man.; and to the best of knowledge Mr Desrosiers is the Supervisor of Construction for the Oblate Fathers of St Boniface.

The information that I am seeking is; Has the Dominion Government, through the Department of Indian Affairs, assisted in any way with a financial grant, towards the New Extension of this School? If so; Do the hours of Labor and Rates of Wages, as established in the provisions of the Fair Wage Act of Manitoba prevail:

It has been brought to our attention that Mr Desrosiers, has hired Bricklayers in Winnipeg to go out to Sandy Bay at the rate of .75¢ per hour, which is not in accordance with the Fair Wage Act of Manitoba, as the rate set by the Board for country work is .90¢ per hour, with a proviso subject to, definite agreements made between Employers and workmen with the approval of the Provincial Government, that men hired in Winnipeg and sent to work in the country shall be paid .90¢ per hour plus .15¢ per hour to cover cost of Board and Lodgings, which category this extension to the Indian School would be applicable.

I hope I have made our position clear, as to what conditions on this project, should prevail, and if through the medium of your office, on behalf of the Dominion Government that, at least, the Owners or Supervisors should see that the Bricklayers employed on the job be paid the Fair Wage Rate as complied with under the Act.

Trusting that you can supply the information requested and take any necessary steps to prevent any infraction of the Act.

Thanking you on behalf of the above Organization.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant, in which you seek information with respect to certain repairs and alterations that are taking place at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

The Sandy Bay Residential School is a government-owned institution, operated by the Oblate Order. It has at this date an enrolment of 75. The Government contributes $165.00 per pupil per annum.

In the estimates of this year provision was made for a grant to the church authorities, on the understanding that an extension and certain repairs would be undertaken at Sandy Bay this summer. I was not aware that the work had started, but it is just possible that arrangements were made whereby the work started immediately following the close of the school for the holiday period beginning July 1.

I am today requesting from the church authorities a statement showing the character of the construction, number of men employed, wages, etc. Just as soon as this information reaches me, I shall be glad to communicate with you again.

Yours truly,

I am just back from a visit to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. It is expected that the new additions as well as the repairs in the old building will be completed by the 7th of October and that the children will be admitted on the following Monday, October 9.

I inspected the beds and mattresses which have been in use up to the present time and I must admit that I was painfully impressed by their dilapidated condition. From: The Office of the Resident Architect, Department of Public Works
Winnipeg, November 2, 1939

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian School, Sandy Bay, Man.

With reference to your letter of October 15th, Mr. Ritchie of this office accompanied Mr. Hoey of the Department of Mines and Resources to Sandy Bay on the 24th ultimo and inspected work done on the Indian school there, and following is his report:

The work completed as follows:

1. New South Wing: Walls 13" clay brick and hollow tile; floors 8-½" concrete on 12" massillon steel joist; 20 year bonded roof on steel decking insulated with 1" rigid insulation board; stairs and landings are concrete and separated from the old building by a 9" brick firewall.

2. New North Wing: Similar in all respects to new South Wing.

3. Old Building: This building has been completely renovated. All wooden stairs were removed, stair wells were floored over and the space made available for school purposes. The northern 30 feet of this building originally contained two floors, these floors were removed and an additional floor added to conform with the remainder of the building and the new additions, all windows realigned. The additional dead load is carried on new steel frame work of 12" I sections and H columns to new concrete footings. The old frame walls and roof remain.

The ground floor corridor partitions have been rebuilt and replastered. Other partitions have been removed, rebuilt or new partitions installed as is noted on the drawings.

The laundry wing was also re-designed and renovated; new plumbing, floors, partitions, etc.

All old buildings have been completed reroofed with asbestos shingles and all recovered with an asbestos siding which has a ¾" rigid insulation backing.

4. Electric wiring; All new wiring in old and new sections in rigid conduit or BX cable.

5. Heating: All existing heating equipment removed. New Dunham Differential System installed and hooked up to new boiler. This system has been inspected and tested satisfactorily by C. A. Dunham Co. Limited.

6. Plumbing: All new plumbing throughout old and new buildings. The old piping and fixtures have been reused where possible. A new 8' x 18' x 8' two chamber concrete septic tank has been built.
built and seems to work very satisfactorily.

7. Water supply: Two new concrete storage tanks have been built. Rainwater storage tank is 16' in diameter and 14' deep. Lake water storage tank 24' diameter and 11' deep. Each tank is built underground, covered with 4' of earth and connected to a new pumping system.

8. Generally: Materials used are sound and substantial. The workmanship is fair. A rough estimate of the work done runs between $85,000. and $90,000.00.

Enclosed are drawings and photographs of above Indian School.

Yours truly,

(sgd.) E. Parkinson,
District Resident Architect.

I am sending forward herewith, for your consideration and for whatever action you may deem necessary, copy of a report on the construction of an addition to the Sandy Bay residential school and certain repairs to the school itself, received by Mr. T. S. Hills, Chief Engineer of the Department, from Reverend E. Lamontagne, O.M.I., Provincial of the Oblate Order, Manitoba, and Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., General Superintendent of Indian Missions of the Oblate Order. I am enclosing also plan of the Sandy Bay building and a report on the additions and alterations that have taken place, received by this Branch from Mr. E. Parkinson, District Resident Architect, Department of Public Works, Winnipeg. You will note that I am attaching a number of photographs of the Sandy Bay building to these reports.

A memorandum dated April 18, 1939, received by this Branch from Mr. C. W. Jackson, reads in part as follows:

"As you know, the Surveys and Engineering Branch are securing a further report on the possibility of impounding the water in the creek which passes close by the Sandy Bay residential school. No doubt, this will be received very shortly. In the meantime, the Minister has approved of the necessary steps being taken to proceed with the construction of the two new dormitories."
dormitories. It is estimated that the cost of these two buildings will not exceed $40,000.*

It is my understanding that an agreement was entered into between the Department and the church authorities with respect to the construction of these dormitories and certain general repairs to the old school structure. We do not appear, however, to have a copy of this agreement on file in this Branch.

In view of the fact that only $40,000 was provided in the 1939-40 estimates for repairs and alterations at the Sandy Bay school, it will be necessary to consider ways and means of meeting the additional expenditure, estimated by the church authorities to amount to $18,750.34.

Dear Sir:

Complying with the request contained in your letter of June 26th, we beg to submit our fourth report on the building of the additions to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

At date of writing the two new wings with connecting passages and fireproof stairways are fully completed, including painting.

The extensive repairs to the school building proper, to the laundry annex and to the tool and workshop have also been completed with the exception of painting. This work is being done at the present time by contract and we expect that it will be completed about December 1st.

We have been asked by the Department, through Mr. C.J. Jackson, to forward a special report on the extensive repairs carried out in the old school building as well as in the laundry annex and workshop. This has been prepared and is attached hereto, as both the construction of the new building and the repairs to the old were carried out in the same time, and as materials were purchased for both without any record being kept of what was being used. We have not been able to secure the figures which we hereby submit are to some extent approximate. However, they have been gone over very carefully by both the contractor and the book-keeper and we are assured that they represent a true picture of the materials used and the wages paid for these repairs.

In our previous report, we mentioned the building of two large cement water tanks to provide water storage until such time as a new pipe line is installed from the lake to the school. These are now in operation and are giving, under the circumstances, satisfactory results.

Last Tuesday, Mr. R.A. Hoey, Superintendent of Training and Welfare, Mr. Gordon M. Ritchie, Rev. Father M. Lemontagne, and Rev. Father Plourde, made an inspection of the work done at Sandy Bay. Whilst we cannot speak for Mr. Hoey or Mr. Ritchie, we might state that they seemed to be quite satisfied both as to the quality of the work done and as to the reasonableness of the amount expended on the project.
