In your letter of September the 27th, you requested information on 3 issues:

1st Credit note for $4.60 from Marshall-Wells Co. We are enclosing receipted invoice in quadruplicate from the above firm. It seems that this was paid directly by the School and is not to be a charge on the new building.

2nd We are also enclosing credit note from the Alip Brick, Tile & Lumber Co. for $4.60. This amount now stands to the credit of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

3rd In our report dated August the 10th, we stated that wages for week ending July 25th were $200.00; the right amount was $200.00. If you will consult page 2 of our Return of Labour for week ending July the 25th you will notice that the sum of $201.00 was extended to page 3 as $201.00. This error was only noticed when preparing our last report.

In your communication of October the 10th you ask for receipted freight invoices for the following amounts:

$ 64.79
$1,280.00
$1,444.75

No account was rendered by the Thorderson Transfer Co. for the first and last of these amounts as weights were not available at the time that the freighting was done. For the $1,280.00 item, you will find a charge of $24.35 in the Thorderson Transfer's account of August the 25th.

Winnipeg, November 2, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian School,
Sandy Bay, Man.

With reference to your letter of October 19th,
Mr. Ritchie of this office accompanied Mr. Hoey of the De-
partment of Mines and Resources to Sandy Bay on the 26th
ultime and inspected work done on the Indian School there,
and following is his report:

The work completed as follows:

1. New South Wing: Walls 13" clay brick and hollow tile;
floors 5½" concrete on 18" mansion steel joist; 20
year bonded roof on steel decking insulated with 1"
rigid insulation board; stairs and landings are con-
crete and separated from the old building by a 9"
brick firewall.

2. New North Wing: Similar in all respects to new South
Wing.

3. Old Building: This building has been completely re-
novated. All wooden stairs were removed, stair wells
were floored over and the space made available for school
purposes. The northern 30 feet of this building originally
contained two floors; these floors were removed and an
additional floor added conform with the remainder of
the building and the new additions, all windows realigned.
The additional dead load is carried on new steel frame
work of 12" I sections and H columns to new concrete foot-
ings. The old frame walls and roof remain.

The ground floor corridor partitions have been rebuilt
and replastered. Other partitions have been removed,
rebuilt or new partitions installed as is noted on the
drawings.

The laundry wing was also re-designed and renovated; new
plumbing, floors, partitions, etc.

All old buildings have been completed re-roofed with as-
bestos shingles and all recovered with an asbestos siding
which has a ½" rigid insulation backing.

4. Electric wiring: all new wiring in old and new sections
in rigid conduit or BX cable.

5. Heating: All existing heating equipment removed. New
Dunham Differential System installed and hooked up to
new boiler. This system has been inspected and tested
satisfactorily by C.A. Dunham Co. Limited.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Sandy Bay Residential School.

Reports on the construction of the above school indicate that the total expenditure for the current year when all accounts, vouchers, etc., have been received, will amount to $58,730.34 which means an over-expenditure of $18,730.34, as only $40,000.00 was provided in 1939-40.

Work on the school has included not only two new wings but a considerable amount of repair work and alterations to the existing central portion of the building. Apparently work was carried out simultaneously on old and new sections and the church officials had some difficulty in separating the expenditures. In an attempt to segregate these costs Fathers Lamontagne and Plourde have arrived at a figure for the old building of $17,808.32. Of the $40,000.00 provided accounts have been paid totalling $39,999.92, and accounts outstanding, as tabulated by our Engineers, total $17,076.95. Accounts are still being received and it is probable that the above figure of over-expenditure is very close to the correct one.

Our Engineering and Construction officers, of course, found it impossible to divide the accounts into new construction and renovations to the old part of the school so that the only conclusion which can be arrived at definitely is that there will be required the sum of $18,730.34 to pay for work carried out at the school this year.

I am attaching a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, a summary of unpaid accounts, a report prepared by Mr. E. Parkinson, District Resident Architect, and the report of the Oblate Fathers by Fathers Lamontagne and Plourde.
There is also being forwarded under separate cover accounts which remain unpaid and which are summarized in the tabulated statement prepared by this Branch.

Summarizing this situation it appears that there is an over-expenditure of $18,730.34. According to figures supplied by the church officials some $17,808.32 was spent on the old building and $922.02 over the $40,000.00 on the new. Consequently it might be said that the Department has carried out its assistance to the extent of $40,000.00 and that the amount of the accounts outstanding is approximately equivalent to the work done on the old building.

Whether or not the Department is prepared to assist in the renovation of the old building to this extent, $17,808.32, is a matter of policy.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

Re: Sandy Bay and Cross Lake Indian Residential schools.

As you are aware, construction work on the above two buildings was undertaken by the Oblate Fathers of Manitoba and by the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin, respectively, under authority of an agreement between the Minister and the Church authorities.

In the case of Sandy Bay School, the amount provided for by the Department in the present fiscal year was $40,000 and from information received to date it appears that expenditure made by the Oblate Fathers will exceed this sum by approximately $21,000.

Under the agreement for the construction of the Cross Lake School, the Department undertook to provide $65,000 and from accounts submitted it appears that the Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin has exceeded the sum provided by approximately $9,000.

I have been advised by the Chief Executive Assistant that the Minister is prepared to pay the accounts making up the over-expenditure to the extent funds may be available from the money provided for the construction of the Port Alberni School in British Columbia. At the present time it appears that some $34,000 is available from the latter project and a Memorandum to Council is being drafted asking for authority to pay or refund to the Church authorities the amount of the over-expenditure as represented by accounts submitted. Some of these accounts have already been forwarded to you.

If your understanding in regard to the additional payments is in accordance with that outlined above, would you kindly advise me if you would like to have all accounts submitted to you for inspection before they are paid by this Branch from the Port Alberni Vote, or if you would prefer that they be checked by our Architectural Division and paid without further reference provided they are considered in order.

J. M. Wardle,
Director.

FROM: The Office of the Resident Architect,

Winnipeg, November 2nd, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian School, Sandy Bay, Man.

With reference to your letter of October 19th, Mr. Ritchie of this office accompanied Mr. Hoey of the Department of Mines and Resources to Sandy Bay on the 24th ultimo and inspected work done on the Indian School there, and following is his report:

The work completed as follows:

1. New South Wing: Walls 13" clay brick and hollow tile; floors 2-1/2" concrete on 12" massilon steel joist; 20 year bonded roof on steel decking insulated with 1" rigid insulation board; stairs and landings are concrete and separated from the old building by a 9" brick firewall.

2. New North Wing: Similar in all respects to new South Wing.

3. Old Building: This building has been completely renovated. All wooden stairs were removed, stair wells were floored over and the space made available for school purposes. The northern 30 feet of this building originally contained two floors; these floors were removed and an additional floor added to conform with the remainder of the building and the new additions, all windows realigned. The additional dead load is carried on new steel frame work of 12" I sections and H columns to new concrete footings. The old frame walls and roof remain.

The ground floor corridor partitions have been rebuilt and replastered. Other partitions have been removed, rebuilt or new partitions installed as is noted on the drawings.

The laundry wing was also re-designed and renovated; new plumbing, floors, partitions, etc.

All old buildings have been completed reroofed with asbestos shingles and all recovered with an asbestos siding which has a 1" rigid insulation backing.

4. Electric wiring: All new wiring in old and new sections in rigid conduit or BX cable.

5. Heating: All existing heating equipment removed. New Dunham Differential System installed and hooked up to new boiler. This system has been inspected and tested satisfactorily by G. A. Dunham Co. Limited.

6. Plumblings: All new plumbing throughout old and new buildings. The old piping and fixtures have been reused where possible. A new 8' x 18' x 8' two chamber concrete septic tank has been built and seems to work very satisfactorily.

7. Water supply: Two new concrete storage tanks have been built. Rainwater storage tank is 16' in diameter and 14' deep. Lake water storage tank 24' diameter and 11' deep. Each tank is built underground, covered with 4' of earth and connected to a new pumping system.

8. Generally: Materials used are sound and substantial. The workmanship is fair. A rough estimate of the work done runs between $85,000. and $90,000.00

Enclosed are drawings and photographs of above Indian School.

Yours truly,

(sgd) E. Parkinson,
District Resident Architect.

Dear Sir:

re: Addition and repairs to Indian Residential School, Sandy Bay, Man.

Complying with the request contained in your letter of June 28th, we beg to submit our fourth report on the building of the additions to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

At date of writing the two new wings with connecting passageways and fireproof stairways are fully completed, including painting.

The extensive repairs to the school building proper, to the laundry annex and to the tool and workshop have also been completed with the exception of painting. This work is being done at the present time by contract and we expect that it will be completed about December 1st.

We have been asked by the Department, through Mr. G.W. Jackson, to forward a special report on the extensive repairs carried out in the old school building as well as in the laundry annex and workshop. This has been prepared and is attached hereto. As both the construction of the new building and the repairs to the old were carried out in the same time, and as materials were purchased for both without any record being kept of what was being used for one or the other, the figures which we hereby submit are to some extent approximate. However, they have been gone over very carefully by both the contractor and the bookkeeper and we are assured that they represent a true picture of the materials used and the wages paid for these repairs.

In our previous report, we mentioned the building of two large cement water tanks to provide water storage until such time as a new pipe line is installed from the lake to the school. These are now in operation and are giving, under the circumstances, satisfactory results.

Last Tuesday, Mr. R.A. Hoey, Superintendent of Training and Welfare, Mr. Gordon M. Ritchie, Rev. Father E. Lamontagne, and Rev. Father Plourde, made an inspection of the work done at Sandy Bay. Whilst we cannot speak for Mr. Hoey or Mr. Ritchie, we might state that they seemed to be quite satisfied both as to the quality of the work done and as to the reasonableness of the amount expended on the project.

Subsequent invoices received on the 9th instant, as well as pay roll No. 25, plus $700.00 provided for unforeseen expenses have somewhat altered this figure.

We wish to take this opportunity to thank you for your valuable advice and guidance in connection with this work. We have very much appreciated your unfailing good will and your readiness to be of help to us at all times and under all circumstances.

Hon. T.A. Gravel,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

My dear Mr. Gravel,

At the risk of a certain amount of bother and annoyance, may I take the liberty of saying that I recently visited the enlarged Indian School at Sandy Bay. It is superb and certainly the equal of any Indian School in this Province. I want to express my sincere thanks to you for your kind consideration and generous response to my appeal.

Not only were the two wings constructed, and happily fire-proof, but very substantial reparations were made in the old building. Now I can feel more at ease, for the lives of the children will be safeguarded against the danger of fire, no matter what might happen. I fear the Fathers spent more money than they were authorized to spend by the Department, but personally I am convinced that it was money judiciously spent. I am told that they exceeded the amount authorized by at least $20,000.00. If the Fathers approach you, I am sure you will give them a sympathetic hearing.

The new building is capable of holding 150 children. There are that many, or almost that many, on the Sandy Bay Reserve. The children must be educated and I hope that the Department will authorize the Fathers to take as many children as may be necessary to fill the school and that the necessary funds will be provided in the estimates of the current year.

With sentiments of the highest esteem,

I have the honor to be,

Your very humble servant,

(signed) Alfred A. Sinnott

My dear Archbishop Simnett:

I have for acknowledgment Your Grace's letter of January 17, in which you refer to your recent visit to the reconstructed Indian residential school at the Sandy Bay reserve.

The reports that have reached me with respect to the construction of the two wings at this school and the general repairs to the main building indicate that the work undertaken has been very satisfactory and that there is ample accommodation in the reconstructed buildings for the children of the reserve, not only at the present time but for a great many years to come. I was very gratified, therefore, to learn that after an inspection of the plant your own views were in accord with the reports that had already reached the Department. I must state, however, that I was somewhat disturbed to learn that the original estimate of the cost of these repairs had been exceeded by the sum of approximately $50,000. If I remember correctly, the first estimate of the cost of the repairs proposed at this school was $25,000. This was later increased to $40,000, on the understanding that the additions would be of fireproof construction throughout. No provision has of course been made in the 1938-40 estimates for the payment of the additional amount referred to in your communication, and this sum, if it is to be paid, will have to be submitted to and passed by Parliament.

I note, also, your request for an additional per capita allowance at this school to enable those in charge -

Most Reverend Alfred A. Simnett, D.D.,
Archbishop of Winnipeg,
358 St. Mary's Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
charge to provide instruction for the additional pupils that can now be accommodated in the building. I can only promise you at this date that I shall be glad to review this request very sympathetically, just as soon as the limited time at my disposal will enable me to do so. In view of the war conditions now confronting us, however, I feel confident it will not be possible to make provision in the estimates of next year for the full quota of pupils at the Sandy Bay school. I shall however do my best to secure the funds necessary to make provision for the instruction of an additional number of Indian children.

Yours sincerely,

During my recent visit to the Sandy Bay Residential School, I made an inspection of the new additions which are evidently fireproof. The old portion of the school has been sided with a pulp composition but it is still an old building. The dormitories, both girls and boys, are in the new buildings, the class rooms etc., being in the old. I was specially interested in the fire protection of the building, which I do not think is adequate. In the case of fire breaking out in the old building, it is expected that the children would immediately be transferred to the fire proof new additions, and from there they would be able to reach the outside. The old building is of frame and, in the event of fire, would burn very fast. I feel that the doors between the old building and the new should be of steel or at least fire-proof. There should also be a means of more readily access from the roofs of the new additions to the ground, and in my opinion, there are not enough hose lines. I am not an authority on fire protection and beg to suggest that an architect or some person with a knowledge of fire protection be sent to the school to look over these matters.

Your obedient servant,

Both of these officials have reported to the Department and we are consequently fully informed regarding the present condition of this building.

It is the intention of the school management to provide fireproof doors as soon as possible.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I attach accounts amounting to $168.38 covering emergency repairs to the water truck used at the Sandy Bay Residential School.

Reverend Sir:

In endeavouring to have passed for payment an account covering the cost of repairs made last spring to the truck used for transporting water the whole water situation at the Sandy Bay Residential School was again brought up for consideration.

There are no funds available in the present year's appropriation for the installation of a water supply system at the Sandy Bay School nor can I hold out any assurance at the present time that this matter can be handled during the fiscal year 1941-42.

However, I feel it would be advisable for you to submit a complete report on the water situation at the present time. I have recently reviewed the report made by Mr. Gow on September 5, 1934. This read in part as follows:

"The existing water supply at the Institution is briefly as follows: The school building is approximately 100' x 40' and rainfall upon the roof is collected into an underground cistern 18 feet in diameter and 10 feet deep, with a capacity of about 7,000 gallons. This cistern is in close proximity to the kitchen and the water is delivered to the kitchen by means of a hand pump located in the kitchen. This water is used for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes. For sanitary purposes three tanks with a combined capacity of 2,200 gallons are located in the attic of the building and a gravity water furnished the school. The water supply to these tanks comes from two sources, but the quality of the water is much the same. A comparatively deep well, approximately 250 feet from the school, is operated by a wind mill."

Rev. O. Chagnon, O.M.I.,
Principal, Sandy Bay Residential School,
Marius, Man.
and a feed pipe leads to the water tanks, the energy necessary also being supplied by the wind mill. A comparatively shallow well is located quite close to the workshop of the school and is connected to an underground cistern nearby; the dimensions of this cistern being about four feet square and sixteen feet deep. A pump driven by a small gasoline engine located in the workshop connects with this cistern and also to the storage tank in the attic and is operated during such periods as continued lack of sufficient wind to operate the wind mill results in failure of water supply from the deeper well. The Principal of the school stated that this shallow well appeared to be going dry. The water from both these wells is very hard and distinctly salty. It is unfit for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes in the school, but I understand that in addition to sanitary purposes it is also used in the steam heating system, high pressure boiler and domestic water heater.

"The amount of water that can be collected into the soft water cistern from the roof, even in a year of average precipitation, is far from sufficient to meet the requirements of the very limited use to which this supply is put and consequently water has to be hauled from Lake Manitoba -- two and one-third miles distant. It appears that only an average of one tank per week is hauled from the lake."

In reporting on the present water situation you should refer particularly to the following:

1. The approximate amount of water that is collected from the roof into the soft water cistern.

2. The number of tanks of water per week that have to be hauled from the lake.

3. Did the well mentioned in Mr. Gow's report go dry? If not, is it still too salty for use?

4. Are you aware of any wells having been dug in the vicinity within the last year from which good water
has been obtained? In that event you should let me know the depth of such wells and their approximate cost.

I should appreciate having your reply at an early date.

Yours truly,

H.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

MR. R. A. HOEY.

Dear Sir:

Answering your letter of the 12th Instant, I beg to say: Mr. Gow's report made on September 5th 1934, described exactly what we had to do at Sandy Bay before construction of two new wings in Autumn 1929. You ask me to answer four questions.

1) In summer 1940, our soft water cistern with a capacity of 7000 gal. was filled about 4 times.

2) We go to the lake three times a day with a tank of 600 gal., at a distance of about 2½ miles.

3) There are two wells mentioned about in Mr. Gow's report; The one near the school has gone dry, the other on which there is a wind mill is still used in summer for the animals but the water is as salty as before.

4) There has been no wells dug recently in the vicinity.

All the water that we use at Sandy Bay goes firstly in a large outside cistern of 25000 gallons, from this it is pumped by the electric plant into 3 pressure tanks installed in the furnace apartment.
With a tank containing 600 gallons we must go to the lake 3 times a day in order to furnish enough water for the school. The winter of 1939-40 having been very mild without hardly any snow and we did not lack of water. With a colder winter and more snow it will be more difficult.

We receive $40.00 a month from the Department for hauling water from the lake to the school. Bad roads, rain, cold, truck repairs, hinder us from making the 3 trips a day, but as the cistern has a capacity of 25000 gallons, we can regain time when everything goes well.

Yours sincerely,

O. Chagnon
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I have the obligation to submit to you a serious problem concerning the supplying of water for our Indian School at Sandy Bay.

For the third time in the last months our truck specially equipped and used for that purpose has been broken seriously and we considered that it is not advisable to have it repaired. This truck has been in use since 1938 and its mileage is 24000 miles for the hauling of water for the school on a distance of three miles in rough roads and sometimes in very bad roads and it is not surprising that serious troubles have happened lately.

May I suggest that an urgent solution be given to this important problem because our storage of water requires it and I take the liberty to suggest to you that this truck be exchanged for a new one with the exception of the water tank and the pump equipment.

Mr. Johannesson at the Langruth Garage would make the exchange for a new Fargo Truck on a basis of about $900.00 in return.

Thanking for the consideration you will give to my request, I remain yours truly,

Dear Sir,-

We have been 10 days without using our truck, for hauling water. It is now the third break down we have had, and I believe it is useless to replace the broken parts. It needs a new engin. The cost of it, including labor, would be in the neighborhood of $200.00

According Jhoanesson Bros. Garage, a 2 ton Fargo Truck with suitable tires would cost $1497.00 less $500.00 allowance on our 1934 Chevrolet truck.

Something must be done at once. We are using water very sparingly, and we are to be without it, before long. I have a team of horses hauling water with a small tank but it is not enough.

Please answer by wire.

Wishing you: happy New Year, I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours sincerely.

Dear Sir:

Concerning the 50ft. of hose asked for, in the previous letter: it should be 50ft. of 2 inch "Rubber Covered and Wire Lined" hose in 3 lengths.

1 - 30ft. length for suction.
1 - 80ft. length for discharging water into tank, on truck.
1 - 10ft. length for discharging water from tank into underground reservoir.

All connections are for 2 inch pipe. Connections at both ends are required, because they are wearing quickly, there is some screwing and unscrewing at every load, so when one end is worn out, we use the other and it gives us time to order a new connection.

If a new truck is supplied, Jhoaneson Garage of Langruth will install the tank on it.

From the 7th of January, we are conveying water, day and night, with horses, it is nearly enough for the daily requirement, but in case of fire it would not be enough and we would be helpless for want of water.

Yours sincerely,

O. Chagnon
Principal

MEMORANDUM RESPECTING PURCHASES OF FORD VEHICLES
DIRECT FROM THE FORD COMPANY

A letter has been received from the Ford Motor Company in which they offer to sell Ford products to all Government Departments on the same basis that is now extended to the Department of Munitions and Supply. This selling plan is predicated on all transactions being made direct with the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Limited, Windsor, Ontario, and does not permit of used vehicles being traded in. The offer is to be effective immediately and will continue in force for the duration of the war unless you are otherwise notified.

The prices charged for purchases on this basis will be considerably less than those for purchases through Ford dealers. It will be appreciated that under this arrangement the dealers will not participate financially and therefore cannot be expected to assume any responsibility for delivery or warranty.

These special prices will be referred to hereafter as the "War Supply Prices" and the prices for products bought in the regular way through the dealers will be referred to as the "Standard Prices".

Treasury Board Minute (T.193643 B., dated April 30, 1940) directs that in certain instances, where a vehicle of a type that is manufactured by the Ford Motor Company is being purchased, the Department concerned must obtain a specific bid from the Ford Motor Company at Windsor, Ontario, on a comparable Ford vehicle at the War Supply Price.

Details of the Company's selling plan are as follows:

SELLING PLAN

1. Tenders
   Invitations to tender are to be sent to the Head Office of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Limited, Windsor, Ontario. The Company will tender direct for any vehicles where no trade-in is involved.

2. Prices
   (a) The basis of price quotations will be the same as that in effect on the Company's quotations to the Department of Munitions and Supply.
   (b) Prices quoted will include sales and excise taxes and will be firm for the period specified in the tender except for any changes in these taxes prior to delivery of the vehicles.
   (c) Prices will include pre-servicing at factory and a filling of oil. Gasoline will not be included or supplied.
   (d) Quotations made will specify all standard and optional equipment and will represent an all-inclusive price delivered at destinations indicated in tenders.
(e) Service parts will be sold to Dominion Government Departments at dealer price less 15% f.o.b., Factory or any of the Company's Branches. Official departmental orders on this price basis will be honoured only at the Head Office, Windsor, Ontario, or at the Branch Offices at Saint John, N.B., Montreal, Toronto, Ont., Winnipeg, Man., Regina, Sask., Calgary, Alta., and Vancouver, B.C.

3. Terms of Payment

In extending these prices to the Government, the Company states that it is a necessary condition that payments be effected promptly and that a limit of 30 days after shipment be the maximum period for extension of credit.

4. Transportation

(a) The Company reserves the right to use the most convenient method of transporting vehicles to destination, including road, rail, transport or boat service. The Government representative, to whom the vehicles are to be consigned, will be designated on the order, and he will be responsible for acceptance and unloading, if necessary, at destination.

(b) Charges for transportation included in price quotations will not be in excess of similar charges to dealers which are based on shipments in carload lots. Should, however, the delivery requested by Government departments necessitate shipments in less than carload lots resulting in higher transportation costs, then quotations will be increased to the extent of such higher costs.

5. Warranty

(a) Manufacturers warranty will extend for a period of ninety days or 4000 miles of operation, whichever occurs first. Claims under warranty will be reported on Form N.D.C.-789 on which will be recorded all particulars such as model of vehicle, serial number, motor number, etc. Parts which are claimed to have failed in operation and consequently have been replaced should be held pending instructions from the Company as to disposition. Form N.D.C.-789 will be forwarded to the Head Office of the Company at Windsor, Ontario, marked for the attention of the Service Department. Examination of parts will be made by the Company's representative at the point where the parts are being held by the department concerned. This location will be indicated on Form N.D.C.-789. Examination and report by the Company on claims will be made in not more than thirty days from the date thereof. In cases where the company wishes the parts in question returned to its nearest branch, transportation costs on such parts will be assumed by the department. Credits for parts which have
been found to be defective will be made at prices at which parts are sold by the Company to the departments concerned. Local purchases made in the field from dealers will be supplied by dealers at retail prices less discount usually allowed by dealers to fleet owners.

(Note.- Form N.D.C.-769 is a Department of National Defence Form, and a copy for reference purposes should be obtained from that Department).

(b) Allowances for labour arising out of warranty claims where such labour is performed by Government departments or outside garages will be made at the Company's current flat rate labour schedule at the rate of seventy-five cents per hour. No allowance will be made where labour expended is less than one hour. Where the operations performed are not included in the flat rate labour schedule the time to be allowed will be mutually agreed upon by the Company and the Department concerned.

The following should be noted in connection with transactions of the nature above referred to:-

(a) Lubrication Service

After initial servicing by the Company, the Department concerned will make its own arrangements to have the vehicle taken care of in this respect at Government expense.

(b) Delivery and Handling

The Department will make whatever arrangements are necessary to take delivery at destination. Costs for such, if any, will be a charge to the Government.

(d) Disposal of Used Vehicle

Where a purchase has been made at the War Supply Price and there is a used vehicle to be disposed of, the Department concerned will, as soon as delivery of the new vehicle has been made, notify the Salvage Officer that the used vehicle is to be sold. Such notification will show the Committee's Application Number which appears at the top of Page One of the Application Form and will include a request that the Salvage Officer quote this number when reporting the sale to the Committee.
Ottawa,
February 21, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

I attach copy of purchase order for a new Ford truck to carry the water at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. In connection with this truck I also attach memorandum respecting purchases of Ford vehicles direct from the Ford Company. Your attention is directed to the different paragraphs in this memorandum.

I wish to draw your particular attention to paragraph 12. You should notify me immediately on receipt of the new truck in order that I may arrange with the Salvage Officer to take charge of the old truck. The latter should be stored at the school until the Salvage Officer disposes of it.

In your letter of January 13 you stated that when the new truck is supplied you can arrange with Johanson Garage of Langruth to install the tank on it. Purchase order No. 5406 was forwarded to you on January 31 covering the hose that you requested in your letter of January 13.

You are well aware of the critical conditions through which we are passing at the present time and as a consequence it will be increasingly difficult to replace equipment owing to lack of funds. Under these circumstances it is most necessary that the management of our Indian residential schools take every possible care of equipment supplied to the schools. With regard to the new truck that has been ordered it should only be used for the transportation of water. It must not be used for any other purpose whatsoever. I feel certain that you will carry out our instructions in this regard.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I enclose 5 Return of Labor for work done at Sandy Bay School, which have not been paid for. You have informed me on your letter, No. 126-9-5 of the 22nd of February: "appropriation practically exhausted" so I have sent no more Return of Labor, though the work continued to be done, by only one carpenter. There is about for 2 weeks of painting to do. Reverend Father Plourde has advised me to forward unpaid Return of Labor for work done at Sandy Bay School.

If one of the Sandy Bay staff were away for these 2 last years, and were coming back, he would hardly believe it is old Sandy Bay School, so many improvements having been made.

Yours sincerely,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th instant with reference to the request for linoleum for the chapel of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

Dear Sir:  

Attention Mr. Ph. Phelan  

Last year the Department was good enough to supply a truck for the hauling of water for the Sandy Bay Indian Res. School. At the present time this truck is housed in a garage which is not built for winter use. It is not insulated, nor is there room in it to put a stove. The Principal would like to enlarge it to provide sufficient room for a heating system of some kind. He has forwarded the enclosed list of material which would be needed for this purpose.

If enlarged as suggested, the garage would be of sufficient size to house the Farm truck which has to be used occasionally to pull the truck out of snow banks in the Winter.

This is an improvement which should really be attended to immediately. Nothing was asked for this purpose in last year's estimates because it was thought that the truck could be kept in the garage as it had been in previous years. Bearing in mind the recommendation contained in one of your previous letters, that particular care be taken of the truck on account of the impossibility in which the Department may find itself to replace it, Father Chagnon is willing to supply all the labour necessary to enlarge the garage if you can supply the material.

Back in 1939 the ice house of the School was burnt and as the Department does not carry insurance on its buildings, the School received nothing to compensate it for this loss. Owing to the fact that the electrical plant is a local affair, it was not thought advisable to supply the School with a frigidaire at the time it was renovated and enlarged. The School has therefore been without refrigeration facilities for the last two years.

Sir,

During a recent visit to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, special attention was paid to the equipment on hand for fire protection. The alarm was checked and I was informed by the Reverend Principal that fire drill was regularly carried out. All hose was inspected and I beg to make the following suggestions. The hand equipment was also checked and I requested the Principal to purchase refills. The account will be forwarded to the Department when purchase has been made. There are two standards that should be cut and made ready for use in the case of an emergency. One hose should be replaced. It has been in the school for fifteen years. The requirements in material to complete the work are as follows:

1-"Y" 50 ft. 1½ inch hose (cotton) 1- nozzle.
1- 2 inch "T", 1- 2 inch "Y", 1- 2 inch coupling, brass lined, 50 ft. cotton hose 2 inch, 1- nozzle.
50 ft. of 2 inch cotton hose.
1- "Y" 1½ inch, 50 ft. 1½ inch cotton hose.

I would also recommend the purchase of a 40 foot extension ladder at an approximate cost of $32.00.

The barn is also in need of repairs before the severe weather sets in. Material requirements were checked and are set out below:

20- pos. 2 X 12 - 12, 1000 ft. 2 X 10 - 10, 75-pos.
2 X 4 - 12, 20-pos. 2 X 6 - 10, 500 ft. spruce sheeting.

The school staff will do the work on the hose standards etc., and repair the barn without cost to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
November 25, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant with reference to additional fire equipment which you consider necessary at the Sandy Bay School. The Department is not exactly certain what you want as you show in two places 50' of 2" cotton hose and also in two places 50' of 1½" cotton hose. Was this duplication or do you want 100' of each width of hose?

As you have previously been informed, an amount of $500.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Sandy Bay School. We have already expended over $492.00. Under these circumstances the material for the barn and the new ladder cannot be authorized.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

MR. J. WAITE.

Dear Sir:-

The Batteries of our Electric Plant are about run down. 3 out of 56 cells have been discarded and some more will be put aside before long.

Had the Electric Plant been used for the work it had to do, when bought (Dec. 1938) i.e., lighting a building of 100-30, it would be good yet.

You know in 1939, two wings have been built; one 34-60 the other 34-60. Our Electric Plant had to light these #2 buildings, to pump 1800 gals. of water every day, to pump the returned water of the heating system, in winter, which requires in the first case a motor of 2 H. P. in the second a motor of three fourth H. P., both motors running 4 hours a day, in winter.

Considering the additional work done by our Batteries, they have done well to stand this length of time. It will be 3 years next January.

I would have asked you, at the time of your recent visit, if I had not written Rev. Father Plourde. The very day of your departure, I received Father Plourde's answer telling me to ask through the Indian Agent.

Yours sincerely,

O. Chagnon, O.M.S.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo with reference to the batteries at the Sandy Bay Residential School. Our records indicate that these batteries were supplied less than three years ago. It is difficult to understand why they have been allowed to deteriorate to such an extent that the Principal claims they should now be replaced. No funds were provided in our current year's appropriation for the replacement of these batteries and under these circumstances the school will have to do the best they can with the present set of batteries until after next April.

I have your letter of the 8th referring to my 2 16½ yrs. old watchmen. Although young, they are performing their work better than the ones I had before. They keep awake, make their round on time, report any unusual thing, if any, on the morning. These boys' father is my mechanic at the school; they work with their father, and are very quick to learn.

Besides watching, the watchman has to fire the heating plant, at night, see that the motor operating the vacuum and the one operating the water pump, work properly.

The reason I have chosen these boys is, I would have no house for a married man, an unmarried man would have to pay his board out of his $40.00 salary. My 2 boys (nearly 17 yrs. old now) are young, but if youth is a fault it is a fault that one can get rid of every day.

Wishing you a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year, I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours sincerely,

O. Chagnon, O.B.
Principal

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant enclosing communication from the Principal of the Sandy Bay Residential School with reference to his request for a new set of batteries. In regard to this request I would again refer you to my letter of December 1, 1941. I expect considerable difficulty in securing approval for the purchase of a new set of batteries for this school, in view of the fact that the present batteries have only been in use for three years. It appears from the Principal's letters that the batteries have been overworked and no doubt this is the reason for the necessity for new batteries at the present time.

Before submitting the matter to the Purchasing Branch, I will require a definite statement from the Principal showing in what manner he intends to handle the services at the school in future in order to avoid such rapid deterioration of the batteries. It is increasingly difficult to even obtain batteries at the present time and this condition may exist for some years. Even in the best of times it is impossible for the Department to consider replacing batteries every three years.

In his last letter the Principal states that he has received a quotation from the Globalite Batteries Limited of Winnipeg in which they state that set No. 17 is the most suitable for the Sandy Bay School. This information is not sufficiently clear for our purposes. We will have to have detailed information regarding

Mr. R. A. Hoey,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We had a brief visit yesterday from the Priest in charge of Sandy Lake Residential School at Marius, Manitoba, and we supplied this gentleman with certain information which he desired concerning one of our 56-cell type W-17 batteries which they would like to purchase.

When one of our service men during his regular travels called at this school last fall, he found that our battery which was in service there was practically ruined due to it being extremely overworked. The battery in question was one of type W-11, 210 A.H. capacity, 3 years old. On checking the load at this installation, our representative found that they should have a battery of more than double this capacity, namely our type W-21 of 450 A.H. On further investigation, our representative found that their present plant will not properly charge a battery of a greater capacity than our type W-17, 560 A.H. There was no doubt but that the installation in the first place was too small, even before the 2 new wings were added to the building.

After thorough investigation, we find that the only suitable and correct recommendation for this school is that they purchase our 56-cell, type W-17, 560 A.H. battery. The Priest in charge of this school, as well as the mechanic who looks after the plant, have definitely assured us that they can and will, discontinue taking service from the new battery for the operation of 2 pumps. These 2 pumps had a drain of about 80 amperes per day from the battery and we are greatly surprised that they even got 3 year's service out of their present battery which is only of 210 A.H. capacity. With the elimination of these 2 pumps, we are quite prepared to guarantee our 56 cell, type W-17, 560 A.H. battery for a period of 7 years.

We trust you will not object to us writing you as above, as we felt it was our duty to give you this information. Any further information you desire will be gladly supplied upon request, and assuring you of our best cooperation at all times, we are,

Yours truly,

To the question "in what manner the Principal intends to handle the service at the school, in the event of the Department supplying new batteries?" my answer is: I will use new batteries only for lighting purposes. By eliminating the 1½ H. P. motor returning water to the heating boiler and the ¾ H. P. motor pumping the daily supply of water, the batteries will be greatly relieved.

But as the IO H. P. Diesel is at one end of the school and the pumps at the other end, we will have to provide a new source of power. A 3 H. P. gas engine with the usual paraphernalia of pulleys, belts, counter-shafts, brackets will have to be supplied.

ACTING DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

With reference to the attached requisition, I may say that the batteries at present in use were supplied in the fall of 1938. Subsequent to that time the building was enlarged and the supplying of additional lighting was an extra drain on the batteries. In addition, it appears that the batteries have been used to operate the motor returning the water to the heating boiler.

Re Purchases of Batteries for Residential Schools.

Recently the Deputy Minister approved of the purchase of new batteries for the Sandy Bay Residential School at a cost of $758.40. It was noted that the old batteries had been overloaded and thereby the life of them shortened.

This is a matter which should be brought to the attention of the Principal of the school in order that steps may be taken to see that every care is taken of the batteries. The new batteries that are being purchased are guaranteed for seven years and there is no reason why they should not last for this period if they are properly looked after.

In connection with similar purchases in the future it is suggested that you should advise the church authorities operating the schools that the batteries should last for the life of the guarantee and if they do not the churches will be expected to replace them at their own expense.

Chief Executive Assistant.

Dear Sir,

I recently inspected the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School and while there the Rev. Principal and the Sister Superior pointed out the need for battleship linoleum to cover the main hall on the first floor. The present floor is badly worn and full of cracks, which make it difficult to clean.

The hall is 142 ft. long, including the front and rear entrance, and the material should be 6 ft. wide. The covering should be AA quality.

If funds are available, I would recommend this expenditure as it will lessen greatly the work now necessary to keep the school clean.

Battleship linoleum is difficult to get but Robinson, Little & Co. have the AA quality in brown at $2.03 per sq yd., and in green at $2.27 per sq. yd. The brown would be satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

I beg to suggest that a chlorinator be installed in the water system at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. The water at this school is brought from Lake Manitoba by tank, emptied into reservoirs and then piped through the school. There has been, from time to time, a few cases of typhoid fever on the reserve, and I believe that the water in Lake Manitoba is contaminated to some extent. I have no idea of the costs involved in the installing of a chlorinator, but it appears to me that the water used for drinking should be treated.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 31, 1942.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

Under these circumstances the Department is unable to favourably consider ordering one at the present time. The only possible solution is to boil the water for drinking purposes before using.

Reverend Sir:

Before leaving Ottawa Father Plourde requested the Department to supply lumber for a new ice house at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. I enclose copy of purchase order addressed to Alexander Kippan, Dauphin, Man. You forwarded this quotation to Father Plourde recently and you should, therefore, interview the firm immediately and arrange for the delivery of the lumber. The quotation did not state definitely that the prices quoted were f.o.b. Amaranth and possibly there will be some transportation charges. If so, the school management will have to be responsible for these. We will only be able to pay an amount not exceeding $370.37.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

March 6th, 1943

Dear Mr Phelan;

Received yesterday yours of the 27th February, with invoices attached to it. The invoices are not for the ice-house lumber, but for the poultry-house built last fall, in which I have now 150 hens, and the children are eating eggs....without this new poultry-house I would not have been able to supply them with eggs, at least once in a while.

Most of the expenses were paid by the School, at the exception though of the wages paid lately, and one set of invoices paid to Toupin Lumber in St Boniface.

Therefore these two sets of invoices are re:poultry-house (one of $121.55 and the other of $160.58). A third one was returned to me by Rev. Father Plourde O.M.I. towards the end of January ($282.13).

In reference now of the letter of the 1st February with the purchase order re: ice-house.

I have put in the order to Mr Kippan as soon as I got the permission from your Department, but received no word yet from Mr. Kippan. Last Fall he had promised me that he would supply me the lumber for the said ice-house. But at this time of the year, it is impossible to get in the lumber because of the roads closed, it will take yet a few weeks or so before we can managed to get out or in with a truck and even with the car.

As soon as I get a reply from Mr Kippan, I'll write again to let you know.

I am attaching these invoices again, hoping that the Department will reconsider them again.

I remain yours very Truly,

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Construction of Indian Day Schools,
CROSS LAKE and SANDY BAY Agencies, Manitoba.

In a memorandum dated January 20, 1938, it was recommended by this Division that a two-room Indian day school with full basement accommodation be established on the Sandy Bay Reserve.

It was recommended also, in a memorandum dated October 28, 1937, that an improved Indian day school of three or four rooms be established on the Cross Lake Indian Reserve.

Dear Sir;

Last winter we had lot of trouble for hauling water...practically no road...our grade going from School to the lake is far too low. That grade-road should be lifted up of atleast a foot and one half. Otherwise the Truck has to go through the snow...which is very hard on the truck itself,and we had to have it fixed last week in Winnipeg.

Many of times after the beginning of the month of January we were out of water...and for this reason I had the boys and girls go to the outside toilets...which is unfare specially towards the girls....but it was impossible to do otherwise...But I believe possible to remediate to that by having the road lifted up...........the estimate is about $300.00 Of course calvets (3) are included in,on that amount.

Reference to Department letter of March 13th 1942, I wish to report that considerable drain is effected on the batteries at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School by a small electric motor of ¼ H.P. running a water system and a ½ H.P. motor running a furnace vacuum system. Both motors operate from the batteries which necessitates running of the Lister engine 15 to 18 hours per day during the winter months and 3 to 4 hours per day during the summer months. This continual drain on the batteries causes corrosion and sediment on the plates and the batteries will not last long under this pressure.

I would recommend that a 3 H.P. engine be purchased for operating the two pump engines.

I also enclose letters from the Principal asking for various repairs for the school.

Repairs will also be necessary to the arch in the fire box of the laundry boiler and to the arch and heating system of the heating boiler. This will be covered in the boiler Inspector's report. As soon as this report is received an expert will be asked to give prices on the work necessary and the cost of same will be forwarded to the Department. These repairs cannot be carried out by the school staff.

Dear Sir,

You are sufficiently acquainted with the conditions that prevail at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School to be spared a long description of the trouble which we are having with the water supply.

But in case the officials of the department are not all as well informed as you are, I might say that the school is now obliged to haul all of the water necessary for various services by truck from the lake. Owing to the swampy lake approach directly opposite the school, we have to go two and a half miles for this supply. There is no regular road leading to the lake, and in rainy weather and in the winter when there are large snowdrifts, the work involved is not only very costly but is also very strenuous. In fact there are days during the winter when the school is without a sufficient quantity of water either for sanitary services or fire protection. It is true that the two wings of the school are fireproof, but the central section is of wood construction, and very inflammable on account of its age.

Would it be possible to include in the forthcoming estimates a sum sufficient to insure a regular water supply. If, however, due to war conditions this is found impossible, I hope that you will at least provide for this essential service early in the postwar period.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Very truly yours,

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Sandy Bay Residential School visited on October 28, 1943.

Paint is urgently needed for the following outbuildings:

1. New storehouse
2. New icehouse
3. New chicken house

All these buildings are finished with spruce lumber and should be painted. Spruce lumber is bad to shrink and unless painted the boards will dry apart. I hope funds are available to provide the necessary paint.

The main barn is in bad condition. This barn is very old and past repairing. The frame is rotted and the upstairs floor is unsafe to walk on, as many of the boards have rotted through. A new barn should be allowed as soon as funds can be made available.
November 5th, 1943.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Attention: Mr. R.A. Hoey

Dear Mr. Hoey,

The present barn of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School was erected about thirty years ago, and is now in a very unsatisfactory condition; so much so, that the Principal is always in fear that the milk supplied to the children will be so contaminated that it will be a danger to their health. There is nothing modern in any sense of the word about the building, and the Principal has asked me to place before you a request for the building material necessary to erect a new barn.

The enclosed list was prepared by a competent builder, and is sufficient to erect a barn 120 feet long by 30 feet wide. I am informed that the lumber is available at the present time, and for prices quoted on the enclosed list. The total expenditure for this material would be $359. If the Department will supply the above, the Oblate Order will undertake to furnish all the labour free of charge.

As there has been some complaints in the past that these agreements were not always lived up to, that the amounts asked for were often insufficient, and that further demands had to be made on the Department, the Oblate Order is willing to give a formal undertaking to the Department to the effect that they will erect the barn complete, and not ask the Department for additional funds for materials or labour.

Would you please advise me as soon as possible if this offer is acceptable, as the School may not be able to secure the necessary material if the order for it is not placed in the immediate future.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Reverend Father Lemire, Principal of the Sandy Bay School, informs me that to his knowledge Alex Kippan is the only lumber dealer in the district able to supply the material necessary for the contemplated barn.

If you will be good enough to look up the old files of the school, you will find that as far back as 1926 an appropriation was made for the building of a barn; but owing to the construction of the Lestock School, Father Chagnon who was then Principal at Sandy Bay was asked to put off the construction of the barn for a few years. With the advent of the depression it was found impossible to appropriate any funds for this purpose.

If the Sandy Bay barn was unsatisfactory and unsanitary in 1926, you may judge for yourself what its condition now must be. Its replacement is considered by the Principal as absolutely necessary, especially in view of the fact that he cannot at the present time keep a sufficient number of milk cows to provide enough milk for the children of the school. As it is now recognized that milk is an essential part of the diet of children and that our Indian children particularly benefit by it, the Principal hopes that his request will be granted.

To provide milk and butter for the children, at least twenty cows in milk must be kept, and the necessary number of heifers must also be provided for replacement. Over and above this, the school needs at least twelve horses to work the one hundred acre farm adjacent to the school and the two hundred acres on the section south of the school which the Oblate Fathers have, for the time being, allowed the school to farm.

The above details will help, I am sure, in drawing up the memorandum which you will wish to send to the Minister's office.

Very truly yours,

June 29, 1944.

The roofs of the two additions to the Sandy Bay Residential School require immediate repairs and some repairs will also have to be made to the plaster in the dormitories where plaster has been damaged by the leaking roofs. MEMORANDUM

October 4-1944.

RE: HEATING SYSTEM, SANDY BAY
INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
ABERATHA, MANITOBA.

In connection with Dr. McGill's request for an examination of the return heating lines at the above, expressed in his memorandum to you dated July 20th last, you are aware that we have now been furnished with a copy of the Boiler Inspector's report requested in our memorandum to you of September 1st, 1944.

With information now available, comment on the situation at the Sandy Bay School is furnished as follows for your consideration:

It appears that when the school was built under the supervision of the Oblate Fathers of Manitoba, the boiler room was built at the same level as the remainder of the main floor and the radiators were installed at floor level. Under these circumstances condensate could not be returned to the boiler by gravity and an electrically operated, automatically controlled vacuum pump was installed. The pump is operated by a 3 hp. motor on current supplied by the storage batteries of the school power plant. It is reported by Mr. Gow that during the heating period, or for eight months of the year, the vacuum pump imposes a heavy drain on the electrical system and that the school authorities had purchased, and proposed to install, a gasoline engine to operate the vacuum pump and remove the load from the power plant.

As no lag should be permitted in the ejection of condensate from the heating return lines, and since the construction of the heating system did not permit gravity action, automatic control is imperative. This could not be provided satisfactorily by engine operation of the vacuum pump and the school officers were so advised by Mr. D. Carnegie, Boiler Inspector for the Manitoba Department of Labour, on his last visit to the school. The Boiler Inspector suggested to the School Principal and the Indian Agent the alternative of converting the system to gravity return by means of changes to the radiators and return lines.

In a letter to this Service dated August 30, 1944 Mr. Gow advised that there was nothing wrong with the heating plant so far as heating the building was concerned; that it would be impractical to have a man giving constant attention to a gas engine on the vacuum pump; and that it would appear necessary to continue the use of the motor with the vacuum pump unless the system was changed to gravity return by

Jv. Mr. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6278, file 584-5, part II)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
raising all radiators and their return lines.

We have no drawings or specifications of the heating system at the school, and without a complete survey by a heating engineer we cannot offer an opinion as to whether the necessary changes are possible. The installation of a gravity return for condensate would demand dis-connection of all heating mains, radiators piping, the installation of wall or ceiling type radiators and possible complete remodelling of the boiler room to provide a pit for the boiler. The operation would be costly and very inconvenient.

Since the cause for complaint is the load imposed on the electrical system, it appears to this Service more reasonable to increase the supply of electrical energy than to attempt to return condensate by gravity in a system designed for vacuum operation.

We have no information regarding how serious the drain on electrical equipment may be, but no break-down has been reported, and it is recommended that, before considering alterations to the heating system, an inspection of the power plant should be carried out and a report obtained covering the definite needs of the school, the capacity of the plant and the total connected load.

T. B. MILLS,

With reference to your memoranda of July 20th and September 8th last, regarding the efficiency of the returning lines of the above heating system, I am enclosing herewith, a copy of a memorandum from Mr. Mills, dated October 4th, which outlines the present situation.

You will note that the return of the condensed steam to the boilers is obtained through the operation of a 2 H.P. motor, and which, during the heating period, imposes a heavy load on the electrical system. A possible remedy would be to increase the capacity of the electric plant, but action along these lines would not be advisable or possible until an inspection of the power plant had been made.

The suggestion that the return might be converted to a gravity system is not favoured by our engineers, since it would be costly and very inconvenient because of the location of the boilers and radiators.

MEMORANDUM.

November 21, 1944

RE: SANDY BAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
AMARANTH, MANITOBA.

With reference to your Memorandum of October 17th last with which you forwarded a copy of Dr. McGill's Memorandum to you dated the 13th ultimo requesting an inspection of the electrical power plant at the above, you are advised that we are now in receipt of a report from Mr. Gow covering an inspection carried out by Mr. W.H.Wallace of his staff.

In previous memoranda on the matter, it has been pointed out that the heating system at the school is working satisfactorily and that the only cause for complaint appears to be the drain on the storage battery unit produced by the operation of the vacuum pump of the heating system. This pump maintains a partial vacuum on the heating return lines for heat distribution and also returns condensate to the boiler. Operation is automatically controlled.

The report has been examined and may be briefly summarized as follows:

From the inspection of the electrical installation and information supplied by the school authorities, it is not considered possible to eliminate any portion of the total connected load. The capacity of the plant appears to be sufficient to meet existing requirements. The periods during which the generator is being operated, however, appear to have been irregular, and possibly the battery has been heavily discharged at times but, when inspected, seemed to be in good condition. It was purchased in May 1942 and was guaranteed for seven years. Mr. Wallace reports that more efficient operation, with less wear on the battery, could be obtained by continuous operation of the generator during the periods of high lighting loads necessary in the morning and evening with the battery floating and the generator continued on line for the length of time required to fully recharge the battery. The generator, under these circumstances, would be running from 8 to 12 hours daily during the winter, but this is not considered abnormal.

J.M.Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.
Regarding the effect of the vacuum pump motor on the electrical system, in maintaining vacuum the motor automatically cuts in about every hour and runs for ten minutes. In returning condensate to the boiler, it cuts in every two minutes and operates for one and one-half minutes. The intermittent starting loads thus produced can be taken care of by the generator while in operation, but at other times create a considerable load on the battery. In this connection the following excerpt from Mr. Wallace's report is quoted:

"This might be overcome, to some extent, by cutting out the vacuum control switch during the night, (battery operation period,) and allowing the pump to operate only on the float switch to return condensate from the accumulator tank to the boiler. If the heating system was installed for vacuum pump operation, the total elimination of the use of the pump for this purpose would seriously affect the efficiency of the system, and not be advisable. However, some consideration might be given to the elimination of the vacuum control during the night when the matter of uniform temperature might not be considered important and when weather conditions are not severe. It is essential that careful operation be maintained in order that the electrical plants with the available capacity function satisfactorily, and such operation, as pointed out above, would appreciably lessen drain upon the battery. If, however, it is desired to give more freedom as to operating times of the generator, another battery of the same type and capacity should be connected in parallel."

With regard to the suggestions advanced by Mr. Wallace in his report, our architect has discussed the matter of eliminating vacuum control during certain periods with the Ottawa representative of the Dunham Company who supplied the vacuum pump. We are advised that the pump, (Catalogue VR-10,) is designed for use as suggested by Mr. Wallace. The result would be slightly reduced temperatures at the extremes of the supply lines while the automatic vacuum control was not operating.

It is recommended, therefore, that until its effect can be observed, the Indian Affairs Branch arrange for operation of the power plant by the school authorities, as follows:

a. During the periods when high lighting loads are required, the generator be operated on line and the battery floating, while being re-charged. Careful observation will be necessary to ensure that the battery is not overcharged.

b. That during the night, at such times as weather conditions permit, the vacuum control feature of the pump be switched off.
It is considered that the recommended procedure should eliminate the danger of exhausting the battery charge, but it is suggested that, after instructions have been issued, observations of the results obtained be reported to this office.

CHIEF ENGINEER.
November 23rd, 1944.

Dr. McGill

As requested in your memorandum of the 18th instant an inspection of the power plant now installed at Sandy Bay Indian Residential School has been made by Mr. W.H.Wallace, an Engineer on Mr. Gow's staff at Winnipeg, and I am forwarding herewith a memorandum from Mr. Mills, dated November 21st, 1944, in which he summarizes Mr. Wallace's report and quotes certain sections of it.

Mr Kippen a déjà transféré la moitié du matériel pour notre établissement. Je veux dire le bois seulement. La facture ci-jointe est bien que tout le matériel de construction doit être livré aux frais du vendeur. Cependant les factures des bois déjà livrés incluent une taxe de 8% et $6.00 pour transport.

J'ai fait le calcul pour le bois seulement.

Voici d'abord le tarif : $141.50 de taxe + $240.00 de transport = $381.50

Supposant le bois vendu à un prix normal de $50 au M, il reste cependant que Mr Kippen conviendra que $175.50 de transport. Ce fut vendu à nous sous nos propres frais.

Un matériel assez considérable n'a pas été figuré lors de l'estimation : - papier, fer, boulangerie, conduits pour eau etc...

Dear Father Plourde,

Mr. Kippen has already transported half of the material for our stable. I mean, the wood only. The enclosed account shows that all the construction material is to be delivered at the expense of the vendor. However, the accounts for wood already delivered show a tax of 6¢ and 8¢ per thousand for transportation.

My calculation for the wood only is as follows:

\[

\$240.00 & \quad \text{transportation} \\
\$381.50 & 
\end{align*}
\]

Supposing the wood were sold at a price lower than $50 per thousand, it remains, nevertheless, for Mr. Kippen to cover the $175 transportation. Which would mean that we must pay $205 out of our own pockets.

Such a large amount of material was not counted upon when the estimate was being made: paper, iron, troughs, water conduits, etc.

Regarding the tax, I wonder if we should not be exempt.

I should be very grateful if you would kindly give me the desired information and advise me about this matter.

Up till the present all has been going well at Sandy Bay. I am certainly fortunate to have Father Chagnon and Father Brugère here with me.

(sgd.) Father Jean Lambert, O.M.I.

Reverend Father Levigne, Provincial, called at this office on the 14th instant requesting a further $2000.00 - $2500.00 for the purchase of materials for the proposed new Sandy Bay Residential School. He claimed the Department had allowed $3500.00 for the purchase of material, but owing to the present high prices and the fact that the specifications for the barn were made by an amateur, and were inaccurate, further moneys were required.

I visited the school on the 18th, went over the plan of the barn and obtained a list of materials purchased and paid for, materials ordered and not paid for, and a list of materials still required.

The barn to be built, will be 118 X 34. The studs will be 12 feet, hip roof shingled, cement floors and cow mangers, steel stanchions to be made of pipes by the school staff. All the work of construction and erection will be done by the school staff and paid labour, the approximate cost is estimated at between $5000.00 - $5500.00. The school is also prepared to pay for all extras that may occur after the amount of $6593.00 is paid by the Department for the materials listed on the attached forms. This will include paint, extra fittings etc. The labour of painting is included in the sum already shown.

A number of blue prints of the barn are being prepared and I requested that a copy be sent to the Department. The blue print will be ready in about three weeks.

The barn will house 32 head of cows, breeding heifers and feeding steers. Stalls for 10 horses. I questioned this number of horses. It appears that the school farm of approximately 100 acres is to be worked by horse power, 2 - 4 horses to do the work to be done by the pupils under supervision. When the farm work is done, two teams are continually required for hauling feed from the other farms owned by the church, one team for hauling wood fuel, and two driving teams are necessary for mission and medical services on the Sandy Bay and Ebb and Flow Reserves. Four box stalls are shown in the original drawing. One is required for the bull, two for calving cows, one for calves.

At the present time the school herd consists of 21 cows (recently freshened) 12 cows still to calve and 44 head of young stock, also 12 horses.
The lists attached are as follows:

1 Material purchased and paid for, $1983.40
2 Ordered, not delivered and not paid for, $1486.00
3 Additional requirements to complete the proposed barn, $3093.60

Total cost of material requirements $6562.00

I would strongly recommend that the barn be constructed the size proposed. Costs are high due to war conditions and the shortage of materials. The material, lumber, seems to be much lower in price than it can be purchased here at Portage la Prairie. There is no doubt that a new barn is very necessary, the old barn seems in danger of collapse and to build a large barn now would most likely render the building of lean-to's at a later date to house additional stock, unnecessary.

July 24, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to advise the Department that there is now a drag-line in close proximity to the Sandy Bay Reserve, making dug-outs for farmers who wish to increase their supply of water.

The water situation at the Sandy Bay Residential School has always been a problem and I beg to suggest that while the drag-line is close to the reserve, a dug-out 100' X 200' be made at the school. The cost would be in the neighbourhood of $200.00. I also strongly recommend that two dug-outs be made for the Indians on the reserve. I would suggest that the two dug-outs be made in open areas in the bush; this would tend to make the Indians build away from the vicinity of Lake Manitoba where there is some congestion. In the winter some Indians are watering cattle at the lake which, in some cases, is one to one and a half miles from their buildings. The cost of the two dug-outs for the Indians use would be approximately $80.00 each, the size 60' X 150'. There would be slight additional costs for wooden pumps and fencing, amounting to $30.00.

The dug-out required for the school might not eliminate the use of the truck for hauling water, as it is doubtful if the water would be fit for human consumption, as it is intended to make the dug-out near a creek so that the spring freshets may be caught and retained.

I strongly recommend that the dug-outs be made at this time. They are necessary and it is doubtful if the drag-line will again be in the district.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, July 27th, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.,

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, the Department approves the expenditure of $200.00 for making a dug-out 100' x 200' at the Sandy Bay Residential School.

Your recommendation regarding two dug-outs for the Indians on the Reserve is being brought to the attention of the officials who handle this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines and Resources, Ottawa

July 30, 1945

I am in receipt of a report from the Rev. J. Lambert, Principal of the Sandy Bay School, regarding the redecoration of the boys dormitory before the commencement of the fall term. This damage was reported in my letter 40-39, June 24th last. The size of the dormitory is 34' x 80', and approximately 125 yards will have to be replastered and all of the dormitory walls and ceiling will have to be repainted.

It seems impossible to get a plasterer or painter to leave the city of Portage and give an estimate for this work. It will also be difficult to have the work done by day work as painters and plasterers claim to have all the work they can do until fall.

Will you please advise if the Department will approve having this work done by day work if it is possible to procure a decorator?

J. Waite
Indian Agent

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.,

The Department will expect you to keep the cost as low as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: 126-9-5, Ottawa, July 27, 1945.

With reference to Department letter of authority above noted, which was in answer to my report of the 24th, idem, I enclose herewith voucher No. P.355 in an amount of $920.50, forwarded by the Mid-West Engineering Co. Ltd., Winnipeg. This is for excavating a dug-out at the Sandy Bay School and certain extras which are shown on the invoice.

On July 24, I received a telephone call from the Rev. Principal of the Sandy Bay School, stating that reservoir digging outfit was in the vicinity of the reserve, and that a reservoir could be dug at the school for the sum of approximately $200.00, plus an additional cost on a mileage basis for moving the outfit. I immediately wrote the Department asking for approval of this amount, also asking for $160.00 for an additional two reservoirs on the Sandy Bay Reserve. Department authority was received July 30th, and the Reverend Principal was telephoned the same date, advised that a sum of $200.00 had been allocated for the digging of a dug-out at the school. On the 23rd ultimo the attached account was received from the Mid-west Engineering Co. Ltd. On receipt of this account, the dugouts authorized for the reserve were immediately cancelled and the Reverend Principal written to, asking for an explanation. The explanation was received this date and is attached hereto. From information received since, I have learned that the firm agreed with the Municipality of Lakeview to excavate dug-outs for farmers in the Municipality on a half share basis. This would not apply to the reserve. It is also apparent, that extra work...
on the dug-out was authorized by the school, amounting to $269.00.

On August 15th, the Reverend Principal was in the agency office in connection with supplies for a water line from the dug-out to the new barn. He brought in a report, furnished by the Engineering Branch, dated Winnipeg, August 13, 1932. There are two numbers on this report, one 124167W and F.15244 W. This report states that the cost of a dug-out 240' X 150' would be $6,050.00.

J. Waite,
