Six small seats are required to meet the present need.

The infirmary floor, dispensary and hall on the third floor
is hard to keep clean and should be covered with battleship
linoleum. It will require 2 rolls of about 60 sq. yds. each
and quality AA should meet the need.

I noticed the sewing machines are very old and a couple are
entirely out of commission. I would recommend they be supplied
with two new machines.

The Sister in the kitchen made an earnest appeal to be supplied
with a meat grinder. She would like a Model 4312 made by the
Hobert Manufacturing Company, Ltd., 634 Rue Notre Dame Quest,
Montreal. The same to have a universal motor for AC and DC.
A machine of this type would serve for grinding meat, bread,
vegetables and is equipment constantly required in a large
kitchen.

The dugout has been completed except for the spill-way. This
work should be authorized so that it can be done before a heavy
flow of water causes a washout. The labor and material required
for this work the Father suggested might cost $250.00.

There is another matter in connection with this dugout that
should not be overlooked and should be attended to at once. The
dugout is 60 to 70 ft wide and over 200 ft long and when full
of water it will be about 10 ft. deep. In order to protect the
children and stock this dugout should be well fenced. The
location is close to the school and if a child slips in it would
be almost impossible to get out on the muddy bank. A close-mesh
well erected fence is essential.

Reverend Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Sandy Bay Residential School on November 27th, Inspector Hamilton writes the following regarding the spill-way:

"The dugout has been completed except for the spill-way. This work should be authorized so that it can be done before a heavy flow of water causes a washout. The labour and material required for this work the Father suggested might cost $250.00.

There is another matter in connection with this dugout that should not be overlooked and should be attended to at once. The dugout is 60 to 70 ft. wide and over 200 ft. long and when full of water it will be about 10 ft. deep. In order to protect the children and stock this dugout it should be well fenced. The location is close to the school and if a child slips in it would be almost impossible to get out on the muddy bank. A close-mesh well erected fence is essential".

It is noted that he mentioned the labour and material cost $250.00. If the material required is over $50.00 it will be necessary to place the order with the Purchasing Branch.

I would also like you to give me definite information regarding the quantity of wire and posts required to protect the dugout. The height of the fence should also be stated.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

With reference to Department letter of the
18th ultimo, 127-1-5, I beg to enclose a report
on the fire protection facilities at the Sandy
Bay School submitted by Fire Chief George Spriggs,
Portage la Prairie.

✓ 1 6 Soda acid type fire extinguishers are re-
quired, 3 for each floor.
✓ 2 I agree with the fire chief that this building
contains electrical equipment, a forge and
welding equipment, is dangerous and a new shop
should be built away from the school proper.
✓ 3 only 1 quart vaporizing fire extinguishers for
fighting electrical fires that might occur in
laundry workshop, engine room, etc.
— 5 Would suggest 6 axes, 2 on each floor including
the basement and workshop.
— 6 The concrete collar is in a partition between the
bake shop and the laundry. A particularly hot
fire is required for baking bread and the con-
crete collar should be enlarged 6 inches all
round. This collar is in a wooden partition.
✓ 7 It seems impossible to obtain a yale or other
self closing device for the doors to the furnace
room. One is also required for Portage School.
These may be purchased at Ottawa.
✓ 8 The fire escape at present from the upper class
rooms is for the children to pass down one flight
of wooden stairs to fireproof stairs in the two
annex'. This would be necessary if fire broke
out during the day while the children are in the
class rooms. The children sleep in the fireproof
building and under present conditions dispersal
is made from inside fireproof stairs. The fire
chief feels that a wide catwalk should be built
across
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

J. Waite.
Indian Agent
Portage la Prairie.

Inspection of Indian School.
Sandy Bay, Indian Reserve.

Dear Sir,

Having inspected the above building on December 27th 1945, I would strongly recommend the following:

(1) At least 3-2½ gal. soda-acid type Fire Extinguishers be placed on each floor, as apparently the water supply available at present, is not sufficient to fight fire with effectively.

(2) 2 nonfreezing type Fire Extinguishers for the workshop which is attached to the School. This building is of all frame construction heated with an old iron stove, contains electrical equipment, a blacksmith forge, and a welding outfit. I consider this building to be very dangerous, as a fire hazard and should be torn down, for if a fire did start in this shop it would surely spread to the School.

(3) 6 - 1qt vaporizing liquid Fire Extinguishers to replace those that are unserviceable.

(4) 6 - qts of Carbon Tet: to recharge above when necessary.

(5) Several fire axes should be purchased, in order to get at concealed fires in partitions etc.

(6) The concrete collar that protects the partition, between the kitchen and laundry, where the stove-pipe passes through it is too small, this should be enlarged.

(7) The door from the furnace room should be made self closing, and metal covered.

(8) There are no outside fire escapes on the school at all. Walks could be made from upper floor of class room, (which is on the 3rd floor or frame part of building) out onto roofs of fire proof annexes at each end of the School. This would necessitate a screened or fenced walk, (to prevent persons being crowded off the roof,) this walk would lead to fire escape from the roof of annex, to the ground.

Or, fire escapes could be built from upper floors of class room.
direct to the ground.

(9) I believe also that outside fire escapes should be provided for the dormitories, for if a fire occurred in the old building the smoke etc would, no doubt cause panic and confusion, and possibly loss of life.

(10) Fire drills should be held at least once a month in order that the staff and pupils might become familiar with getting out of the building in an orderly manner, and learning the use of the fire fighting equipment.

I was very much impressed with the neat and clean condition of the whole school, it is a credit to all concerned.

I am,
yours truly,

Geo. H Spriggs

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS & ENGINEERING BRANCH

Re: Sandy Bay Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Manitoba.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man., recently took the Fire Chief from Portage la Prairie to inspect this school, with a view to determining if reasonable precautions have been taken to prevent loss of life in case of fire. The Fire Chief reported as follows:

"There are no outside fire escapes on the school at all. Exits could be made from upper floor of classroom (which is on the third floor of frame part of building) out onto roofs of fireproof annexes at each end of the school. This would necessitate a screened or fenced walk, to prevent persons being crowded off the roof. This walk would lead to fire escapes from the roof of annex to the ground. Or, fire escapes could be built from upper floors of classroom direct to the ground.

"I believe also that outside fire escapes should be provided for the dormitory, for if a fire occurred in the old building the smoke, etc., would no doubt cause panic and confusion, and possibly loss of life."

In my memorandum of January 29, 1946, I requested you to arrange to have one of your officials visit the Portage la Prairie Residential School. When he is visiting that school, Mr. Waite would be willing to take him to Sandy Bay, where he could inspect the building, with a view to ascertaining what is the best manner of carrying out the Fire Chief's suggestions. I trust you can arrange this.

Re: Sure Grip Tires and Tubes and 1 set of heavy duty Truck chains for Sandy Bay Indian Residential School

Dear Sir,

On January 17th, 1946 we supplied:
6--700 by 20 Sure grip tires
6--700 by 20 Sure grip tubes
1 set heavy duty Truck chains as per your order for Sandy Bay School. This order called for no discount on prices regarding tires whatsoever. The tubes, your order did state less 10% plus 10, which appeared to me out of order, however, we shipped the goods together with heavy duty Truck chains and submitted our bill to your Portage agent, in the amount of $414.48. We received your cheque No. 854 for $344.48.

On February 28th we wrote your Portage office submitting the statement of how this account was made up and asking that the cheque for the balance of $69.92 be forwarded. He replied under date of March 1st stating that to the price of tires there should be deductions of 10% plus 10 to this price which amounts to $65.72. I would point out to you that these arrangements were not on the purchasing order, as this simply means supplying goods absolutely wholesale, which appears in my opinion, a system of doing business which no dealer could exist under. Had these stipulations been made clear in your order, we can assure you, we would have made no effort to fill the order. Therefore we request a cheque in the amount of $69.92 being the balance which we feel is due us.

Yours truly,

Pursuant to the authority conferred by Order in Council P.C.-9995 dated November 3, 1942, and any other enabling Order in Council or Statute, and with the approval of the Chairman of the Wartime Industries Control Board and the concurrence of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board,

IT IS HEREBY ORDERED AS FOLLOWS:

1. Section 17 of the Rubber Controller's Order Rubber 4 Amended

Section 17 of the Rubber Controller's Order No. Rubber 4, dated June 30, 1943, is amended as follows:

(a) by deleting from the heading to the said section the word 'used'; and

(b) by re-designating the said section as subsection (1) of Section 17; and

(c) by adding to the said section the following subsections:

"(2) The maximum price at which any authorized dealer may sell a new tire or a new tube to a consumer for use on a truck shall be as follows:

(a) if the consumer owns and operates not more than four trucks, the price shown on the published printed price list for the brand of the tire or tube purchased, which became effective during the basic period (15th September-11th October, 1941);
(b) if the consumer owns and operates more than four but less than twenty-five trucks, the price shown on the published printed price list for the brand of the tire or tube purchased, which became effective during the basic period (15th September-11th October, 1941) less a discount of 10 per centum of such price;

(c) if the consumer owns and operates twenty-five or more trucks, the price shown on the published printed price list for the brand of the tire or tube purchased, which became effective during the basic period (15th September-11th October, 1941), less a discount of 10 per centum of such price, and a further discount of 10 per centum of the price resulting from the deduction of the first discount.

(3) Every sale by an authorized dealer of a new tire or a new tube to a consumer for use on a truck which complied with the provisions of subsection (2) of this section shall be deemed to have been made in compliance with the provisions of subsection (4) of Section 7 of the Wartime Prices and Trade Regulations."

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Fire Escapes,
Sandy Bay Residential School,
Amaranth, Manitoba.

You will recall that following our request to Mr. Gow to carry out an investigation of the nature and approximate cost of changes required to comply with suggestions advanced by the Portage la Prairie fire chief, we were advised that the investigation would not be carried out until road conditions in the area improved.

Mr. Gow has now furnished us with a report on an investigation carried out by Mr. Rose of his staff, which is confined to methods of execution, and structural work involved, but furnishes no estimate of cost for metal stairs and balconies, which constitute the usual type of fire escape.

Comment on the report is furnished as follows:

1. Description of Building - The central portion of the school building is of frame construction. The third floor of this portion contains a central corridor about 3'-0" wide serving three classrooms. Interior stairways, about 21'-6" wide, are located at each end of the floor area, one of which is in a classroom and enclosed by a partition and door; the other opens directly off the corridor and is not enclosed.

At each end of the frame structure are what the report calls "fire proof" annexes, the roofs of which are 3 inches below the finished third floor level; these annexes contain dormitories, chapel and a hospital ward.

Comment - The National Building Code requires a minimum width of 3'-0" for interior stairways in buildings of this character, and both stairways should open directly off the corridor. As the requirements are not completely fulfilled, the proposal for additional exits may be considered reasonable.

2. Additional Exits - The report suggests that an additional exit be formed in the north classroom by converting an existing window into a fire exit door to the annex roof and build a fire escape from that level to the ground. At the opposite end of the corridor and adjacent to the existing stairway, that a further exit door be constructed in the existing frame wall to give access to the annex roof at that end. It is suggested that an additional dormer would provide shelter for the new doorway at this point. The existing stairwell would be enclosed by a door and partition. Both exit doors to annex roofs would be equipped with panic bolt locking devices.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
Comment - An objection to the proposed exits is their proximity to the existing stairs. As no other location seems feasible other than providing exits direct from the classrooms to outside stairways, the possible hazard of these new exits being rendered unusable by smoke or fire from the stairwells may, with reasonable security, be overcome by providing self-closing doors opening towards the stairwell landings.

3. Electric Lighting Signs - The report further suggests a system of exit lighting be provided for all exits throughout the School building, to be controlled by a switch located in the first floor main office.

Comment - As the residents and occupants of a residential school would in all probability be quite familiar with stairways and exits, there seems to be some doubt as to the necessity of the suggested electric light exit signs. Painted "Exit" signs would seem to be sufficient, especially for day occupied classrooms.

4. Protection Against Prowlers - The school principal desires that access from the ground to the annex roofs be prevented, and the suggestion is made that a covered or screened passageway be constructed from the new exit doors to the top landing of the proposed iron fire escape at the parapet wall of the annexes, and extended over the landing. It is stated that this method of egress would be better than erecting a fence around the entire 18 inch high parapet walls and would afford better protection against pupils falling off the roof.

Comment - The proposal of a covered passage over the annex roof, unless of fire-resisting construction, would seem to constitute an additional fire hazard, and the confined space of the passage might be productive of panic.

A properly constructed guard railing around the parapet wall with no opening greater than 6 inches would seem sufficient to prevent accidents and would allow quick dispersal of pupils from the exit doors.

The lower flight of the fire escape would be held in an "up" position without a lock or locking device and would be fitted with an approved counterbalancing device that would permit it to be quickly and easily brought into position for use. It is felt that this arrangement should discourage possible prowlers.

5. Alternative Proposal - The report explains that an alternative proposal by the Fire Chief, of erecting outside stairways from the classrooms direct to the ground, has certain objections.

(a) The outside stairway would be longer.
(b) It would be attached to frame construction.
(c) Access to the outside stairway would be through intervening classroom desks.
(d) A fire escape thus located would not serve the dormitories.

Comment - It is felt that Mr. Gow's objections are sufficient to condemn this proposal.

6. Conclusion of Report - The report concludes with a recommendation that a small portion of the roof where shingles have been torn away by the wind, be repaired and small repairs be made to the conductor pipes and eavestroughing at this time, when the cost could be held to about $25.00. The report gives an estimate of cost as follows:

| Description                          | Cost   |
|--------------------------------------|--------|
| Install Fire Exit Doors & Dormer    | $223.50|
| Install Exit Light System            | $110.00|
| Total                                | $333.50|

No estimate of the cost of supplying and erecting remainder of equipment has been supplied.

After a study of the sketch plan attached, and taking into consideration the factors described in the report, it is suggested that the following method of providing additional exits from the third storey be given consideration.

(a) Form exit door from window in north classroom and on exit door in the corridor south wall to adjoining annex roofs. Exit doors to be equipped with panic bolts.

(b) Enclose south stairwell with a door and partition. Doors to both stairwells to be hung to open upon stair landings and be self closing.

(c) Erect iron fence 2'-6" high above parapet walls of both annexes. No opening in fence to be greater than 6 inches.

(d) Erect an approved type of iron fire escape on north and south walls of annexes, the bottom flight to swing to "up" position when not in use.

(e) Place approved "Exit" signs over exit doors, to be provided by the School Staff.

Under this proposal, our estimate of cost of the completed work is in the vicinity of $2100.00, made up as follows:

(1) Install fire exit doors & dormer $ 223.50
(2) Supply and erect iron fences 510.00
(3) Supply and erect 2 iron fire escapes 972.00
(4) Erect frame partition and door 40.00
(5) Workmen's Compensation & Insurance 150.00
(6) Contingencies & Supervision 189.55
(7) Total $2085.05

In view of the difficulty in assessing Contractor's prices for work at this location and the limited information available from the sketch plan, this estimate can only be considered approximate. If the work is carried out, competitive tenders should be obtained in Winnipeg.

It is suggested, however, that this proposal and estimate be submitted to the Indian Affairs Branch for their consideration.

Attached is the sketch plan which accompanied the report, on which we show in coloured crayon, the suggested location of the proposed iron fire escapes. May we have this sketch plan returned for future reference.

Enclos.

Chief Engineer.

During a recent visit to the Sandy Bay Residential School the following repairs were brought to my attention.

It is readily understood that the plant has been overloaded, doing three times the work it was originally intended to do.

The set of batteries installed in May 1942 have been doing triple the job also, with a result that they are worn out. The school management feels that it cannot take up on itself the responsibility of starting a new school year with the lighting system in its present condition, and absorb the cost of emergency repairs on such equipment.

Dear Mr Phelan,

In reply to your last letter of July 24th with reference to our requisition dated June 28th, may we state that that requisition was prompted by the necessity of the different articles requested, become now more urgent by the impossibility of procuring them during the war years.

The present lighting plant is composed of a 10 H.P. Diesel motor and a Kilowatt generator. It was installed in 1938 to serve the old building only, that is, before the present two additions were built by which the school was tripled in size. It is readily understood that the plant has been overloaded, doing three times the work it was originally intended to do.

The set of batteries installed in May 1942 have been doing triple the job also, with a result that they are worn out. The school management feels that it cannot take up on itself the responsibility of starting a new school year with the lighting system in its present condition and absorb the cost of emergency repairs on such equipment.

The present water truck supplied in 1941 has been doing hard and rough work ever since, especially during the winter months, the reservoir or tank attached to this truck being too small, more tra-
welling was needed by the truck. The school management feels that even if the present truck were repaired, it would still be unable to furnish the work as it is too small to do the job properly and especially economically. Since sending in our requisition of June 26th, we have had the opportunity of taking information on our trucking problem and a 3-ton Army truck with four wheel drive single wheel, capable of carrying a 2000 gallon reservoir with a 3 inch pump on take-off was strongly recommended. The truck is available from War Assets through the Manitoba Federation of Agriculture. We hereby ask authorization to make the purchase. This manner of proceeding is expedient and economical.

We enclose a copy of our requisition for the water system for the barn. This material is now urgently needed as the season is advancing and installation must be completed before fall. As things are now, we are unable to use the water in the dug-out, as we have no pump to bring it to the barn.

May we add that a ready supply of water is absolutely necessary in case of fire, and we have considered it in making our requisition for a larger truck. The other articles asked for are needed and were requested because they are needed.

Re: Truck for transporting water at Sandy Bay School

Last Saturday September 21st, I received your letter advising me that you had entered into negotiations with the War Assets Corporation for the purchase of a 3-ton truck which you described.

As early as Monday morning I sent a mechanic who could judge the value of the truck; his report was favourable although he could not start the engine because the batteries were missing. The price of the truck is reasonable enough but it will be necessary to add the cost of batteries, spare tire, and a jack; it would also be advisable to purchase a tank of greater capacity than the one actually on hand at Sandy Bay which contains only 600 gallons, thus necessitating numerous trips; the Vulcan Iron Work could build a tank holding 1200 gallons; the price was not stated but they usually are reasonable.

Finally it would be advisable to buy a pump operated by the truck engine which would fill the tank with water from the lake; the Fairbanks Co. and the Crane Co. sell this kind of pump. The engine used until now was very inadequate because during the colder days of winter it would freeze and result in numerous useless trips.

To sum up this truck would answer the need provided that the Dept. assumes the additional cost of batteries, spare tire, tank and mechanism for the pump; these would be required anyway with any kind of truck.

While the problem of increased per capita grants for residential schools is being considered, I would like to bring to your attention the need for more mechanical equipment for the kitchens of our residential schools.

The dietary surveys of our residential schools by the nutritionists of the Department of National Health and Welfare point out the need for such equipment. The pressure also from Indian groups to have their children in residential schools spend more time in the classrooms could be alleviated by the introduction of such equipment.

The one item that would particularly do much to eliminate such drudgery would be the potato peeler. It requires neither great manual dexterity nor intelligence to peel potatoes and we cannot truthfully claim that the Indian children so employed are being taught "cooking".

Certain schools with good farms have, by reason of the profits thus obtained, been able to buy such machines. The management of the majority of our schools have not been able to afford such equipment.

I would recommend that consideration be given to a policy of providing a minimum of kitchen machines for our residential schools. Dr. Pett, Chief of the Nutrition Division of the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6278, file 584-5, part 12)
Department of National Health and Welfare, could be approached to prepare a scale of issue for these schools depending upon their pupilage.

I do not recommend the purchase of such elaborate equipment as dishwashers, slicers, etc.

I do feel, however, that a 15 lb. potato peeler costing approximately $200.00 would do much to eliminate many child hours of drudgery and would enable the management to have these hours spent instead in the classroom. In fact we would insist that the school management have a definite increase in classroom hours in return for the provision of such equipment.

I attach copies of letters recently received concerning the supply of such equipment. I have also received representations from Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, in this connection.

Encl.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, 20 December 1946.

MEMORANDUM:

December 28th, 1946.

Re: Fire Escapes, Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, Amaranth, Manitoba.

Following recommendations from this Service regarding the above, the Indian Affairs Branch, under date of August 1st last, approved the installation of fire escapes at an estimated cost of $2,100.

Mr. Gow was requested to obtain tenders for the supply and erection of the fire escapes, together with structural work involved, in making them readily and safely accessible to the pupils.

Firms in the Winnipeg area, due to material and labour shortages and accumulated volume of other work, appeared reluctant to tender.

However, late in October last Mr. Gow obtained and forwarded tenders for work as follows:

October 26th, - Canadian Rogers Sheet Metal and Roofing Ltd., Winnipeg (All phases of the work)........... $1,995.00

October 30th, - Dominion Bronze and Iron Ltd., Winnipeg. (Supply and erection of fire escapes only)............. $ 3,325.00

Mr. Gow had expected tenders from other firms, but to expedite handling of the matter, before the arrival of bad weather, he forwarded those he had received by the end of October to this office for our consideration.

The above tenders were analysed and on November 8th our Purchasing Agent was requested to issue a Purchase Order to the Canadian Rogers Sheet Metal and Roofing Ltd., covering the whole installation at their quoted price. The Purchase Order was issued on November 20th last.

Immediately upon receipt of the order the Canadian Rogers people wrote Mr. Gow advising that a serious error in their tender prevented them from accepting the order. This information, accompanied by the Company's letter, was forwarded to us under date of November 27th last. Mr. Gow was immediately requested to ascertain from the Canadian Rogers firm what adjustment would be necessary for a corrected tender.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

(over)

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6278, file 584-5, part 12)
Mr. Gow wrote us again on November 26th forwarding a third tender. This had been submitted by the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works Ltd., of Winnipeg, under date of November 27th, and stated that they would carry out the whole of the work for $5,209.00. In Mr. Gow's letter he advised that he was awaiting a revised tender from the Canadian Rogers Company.

Under date of the 26th instant Mr. Gow advised us further that the Canadian Rogers Sheet Metal and Roofing Ltd., were not interested in submitting a revised tender. Following this advice, the Purchase Order to that firm was cancelled.

Regarding the tender submitted by the Dominion Bronze and Iron Ltd., the following extract from Mr. Gow's letter of the 20th instant is quoted:

"Mr. Burd advises by telephone that his Company are prepared to carry out the work in accordance with the price quoted in their quotation. However, some of the material necessary for the fabrication is not presently available and it might be necessary to substitute some other material which however, would be as satisfactory as that originally quoted upon. They would not, however, be prepared to carry out this work immediately. It might be pointed out that their quotation does not include the alterations necessary within the building itself to provide exits or does it include patching of plaster walls which might be damaged by the construction work. They are not willing to undertake this phase of the work at all. Their quotation, however, does include the sum of $80.00 for sending an engineer to the building to take necessary measurements."

The work which Mr. Gow advises has not been included in the Dominion Bronze and Iron Ltd., tender is essential to the use of the fire escape and must be carried out as one phase of the work at the same time as other operations. We estimate it would cost in the neighbourhood of $500.00, and in conjunction with work by the Dominion Bronze and Iron Ltd., would produce a total cost of approximately $5,225.00.

The tender submitted by the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works Ltd., is considered too high.

After considering the whole matter, it is felt that winter conditions having arrived before operations could be undertaken, and having no assurance that the work would receive early attention, the project should be deferred until the spring and the funds now transferred to us be returned to Indian Affairs. New tenders should be invited next spring to include both interior and exterior work, and at least $4,000. should be made available by Indian Affairs for the project.

J.T. Miller
Chief Engineer.
